He showed us the photos of the interior and exterior of the House of Worship and finally gave us a few as souvenirs. He was not a Bahá'í; apparently, a friend had given him the photos.

Since Mehrangiz Jan was moving around the ship in a sari, many of the passengers, some of whom were residents of Aden and Zoroastrians, quickly found a way to open a conversation with her and, with her sincerity and warmth, included her in their group. As a result, from the second day, we all had lunch and dinner at the same table. They were very surprised by our acquaintance and early marriage and the strange ten-day marriage process and how the groom was from a Muslim-born family and the bride from a Zoroastrian-born family, yet both were Bahá'ís. This issue led to long conversations and clarifying the matter and explaining the laws and teachings of the Bahá'í Faith with Mehrangiz dear's translation and the special attention that most of the Zoroastrian women traveling with us had. Most importantly, the sincerity and warmth that dear Mehrangiz showed towards each of the women added to the continuation of the discussions. So much so that during the journey from Bombay to Aden, which lasted seven days and nights, an incredible intimacy developed between our small Zoroastrian fellow traveler community and even the gentlemen present in the group with the two of us. They expressed the utmost affection towards us and provided complete companionship in disembarking at the port of Aden.

From Bombay, I sent a telegram to Mr. Mohammad Mehdi Moulavi, the dear pioneer of Aden, who was indeed the conqueror of Aden, and his name was inscribed on a golden tablet installed by the beloved Guardian in the Holy Land, informing him that on such and such a date, I would arrive in Aden with my wife. Since upon disembarking, we had to mention the address of our residence at the immigration office and had no information about the hotels and other places in Aden, I had requested him to come to the ship for a meeting and guidance. Of course, our confidence in the presence of the Zoroastrian community fellow travelers on the ship was also high.
Aden is composed of four regions:
1. **The ship entry area or port**, known as Tawahi. This area was home to major companies and commercial offices, and most of our Zoroastrian fellow travelers resided there.
2. **The Crater area**, where most Indians and Arabs lived.
3. **The Sheikh Othman area**, which was exclusively inhabited by Arabs.

4. **Little Aden**, where the oil refineries were located. These were built by the British after the nationalization of oil in Iran during Dr. Mossadegh's time. Most of the residents in this area were British.

The purpose of introducing the four regions of Aden was to explain that since Mr. Moulavi wanted to associate with Arabs, he had a house and shop in the Sheikh Othman area. Mr. Moulavi was the son of a cleric and became a believer after extensive research and investigation by the famous Bahá'í preacher, Mr. Eshragh Khavari. During that period of investigation, Mr. Javad Ghochani, the brother of his first wife, also participated in the truth-seeking sessions and, being a prominent and first-class lawyer, confirmed the Bahá'í Faith.

I remember in 1954 when the Bahá'ís in Mashhad were in danger, a large number of Bahá'ís from Mashhad, including Mr. Moulavi who had come to Mashhad, went to the village of Cheshmeh Gilas, a famous summer resort in Mashhad. At that time, my elder brother Mr. Mahmoud Kholousi was in charge of managing that village, and they stayed there for a while to avoid the noise of hostility and enmity. In Mashhad, with the efforts of Mr. Eshragh Khavari, who was Mr. Moulavi's preacher and guide in his migration, before returning to Aden, he married Miss Mahboubeh, the eldest daughter of Mr. Navayi, who were immigrants from Ashgabat.

In 1953, at the beginning of the Great Spiritual Jihad Plan, Mr. Javad Ghochani was the head of the Spiritual Assembly of Mashhad. He later migrated to Turkey and became very successful and confirmed. May his soul rest in peace.

Since Mr. Molavi's father was a Hojjat al-Islam and had a Pakistani passport, Mr. Molavi was able to obtain a green card for Aden with his Pakistani passport. At that time, they did not grant residency in Aden to Iranians under any circumstances.

Mr. Molavi owned a bookstore. When we arrived in Aden in 1960, his first wife had passed away, and as previously mentioned, he was residing in Aden after remarrying Ms. Mahbubeh Navaei. They had a daughter named Elham, who was about one year old, and his wife was pregnant and gave birth to a son named Kian.

At the time of writing these pages, dear Kian is a promising young man engaged in religious services and resides with his family in the United States. Dear Elham, after marrying and starting a family, has had children and ascended in Yemen. Mr. Molavi had two daughters from his first marriage. One of the daughters got married in Mashhad, and the other was an immigrant in Aden.

In previous correspondence with Mr. Molavi, I had requested him to write down his exact address for me so that if the immigration office asked us upon disembarking in Aden, I could give his address as my own. Mr. Molavi kindly wrote his address as 'Sheikh Othman, Molavi Bookstore.' We did not know that Sheikh Othman was a small town, and on the other hand, the bookstore name was written in a broken manner, so at the immigration office, we wrote the address as 'Mr. Sheikh Othman Molavi Bookstore,' which caused astonishment and, after a while, laughter from the passport officer. After a few minutes, with Mr. Molavi's presence, the issue was resolved well.

We entered Mr. Molavi's home in Aden, and Ms. Mahbubeh, Mr. Molavi's wife, whom we knew from Mashhad, showed us great kindness and hospitality. In Aden, we discovered that a few days before our arrival there, Ms. Farideh, Mr. Molavi's daughter, had married Mr. Dariush Mahmoudi, who was an immigrant in Sana'a, and they had moved to Sana'a.

From Aden, we had to travel by car to North Yemen. The distance from the first city in North Yemen to Aden was about seven hours, called Taiz. After staying in Aden for a few days and preparing some essential living items, with the guidance of Mr. Molavi and his wife, we set off by car at ten in the morning and reached the city of Taiz, which at that time also held the title of the second capital of Yemen, by early evening.

Upon reaching the city gate, they prevented the car from entering the city and announced that since it was approaching twelve o'clock and there was a curfew from twelve until morning, entry into the city was prohibited. I must explain that in Yemen, the clock starts at sunrise and ends twelve hours later at sunset. They did not follow the 24-hour day-night cycle. Although Aden was a British colony and one of the cities of South Yemen, as soon as you entered the territory of North Yemen, where the government was in the hands of the Imam of Yemen, the time changed, and you had to adjust your watch to the local time. That is, the sunrise and sunset were the basis of the Yemeni clock.

In short, they made us get off the car outside the city gate. I asked the driver to at least give us a place to sleep. The driver spoke with the relevant officer and stated that this couple had just gotten married and, with the Imam's permission, were heading to Sana'a. The officer, upon hearing the Imam's name, kindly gave us a small room made of a few pieces of wood and mud so that we wouldn't freeze to death from the cold overnight. The other passengers each lay down on the ground in a corner and kept themselves warm with the heating equipment they had. We, who were unaware of the curfew and didn't know we needed to bring a blanket, would have frozen by morning if it weren't for the officer's kindness.

In short, with great difficulty, we entered the small room. The space was so cramped that we slept head to toe and stayed awake until morning. In the morning, when we got into the car to move into the city, we realized that the small room had been the guard dog's room, and that night, the animal was homeless because of us. We entered the city of Taiz, and with the driver's guidance, since there was no inn and we didn't know anyone, we went to the guest house.

The guest house was a multi-story building where the Imam's guests and foreigners who entered Taiz were accommodated, as there was no hotel, and it served as a hotel. Yemen had four major and large cities:
1. **Sana'a**: The capital of the country in the north.
2. **Taiz**: The winter capital in the south.
3. **Hodeidah Port**: On the Red Sea.
4. **Saada**: North of Sana'a.
Sana'a is the highest point on earth above sea level after the Pamir Plateau and has an interesting and pleasant climate.

We settled in the guest house. Since the plane was going from Taiz to Sana'a the next day, we stayed one night in the guest house. Indeed, the food was good, and the rooms were tidy and comfortable, especially compared to our first night in Yemen. We went to buy plane tickets. It turned out that the plane ticket from Taiz to Sana'a cost about fifty Yemeni rials per person. The Yemeni rial was a pure silver coin, each thousand of which weighed twenty-seven kilograms and was slightly more expensive than the US dollar at that time. These coins were made during the time of Maria Theresa in Europe and were once circulated in Austria. I don't know how they became the currency of Yemen. My surprise increased when I learned that the return ticket, from Sana'a to Taiz, was 47 rials. When I asked the reason, they said that since Sana'a is at a high altitude, the fare to Sana'a is higher, even by plane. After a two-hour flight, the plane landed in Sana'a. At the airport, Mr. Abdullah Anwar and Mr. Nadeem Shahidi, who were supposed to be my mentors, came to welcome us.

After the initial greetings, we left the airport and went to Mr. Nadim Shahidi's house, where they had prepared a room for us, and we were welcomed by his wife. That night, the rest of the Bahá'ís residing in Sana'a came to meet us, and a very friendly gathering was formed.

In this section, I must introduce Mr. Abdullah Anwar, who was the pioneer in Yemen. Mr. Abdullah Anwar lived in Sana'a with his wife and a young son named Hossein. Mr. Abdullah Anwar was from the Jewish Bahá'í community of Hamadan and was a member of the youth committee in Tehran before the announcement of the 45-month migration plan by the National Spiritual Assembly of Iran. On the night of his wedding in Tehran, instead of going to the bridal chamber, he was imprisoned and spent some time in jail.

One day, Mr. Anwar recounted that during Reza Shah's time, problems arose for the Bahá'ís in Tehran, and the government demanded the names of the committee members from the secretary of the Tehran assembly. They only gave the name of Mr. Abdullah Anwar, who was apparently the secretary of the youth committee, to the authorities. After being released from prison, he and his wife set out for Baghdad at the beginning of the 45-month migration plan. In Baghdad, God blessed them with a son, whom they named Hossein. However, divine will did not favor his survival, and he passed away in childhood. This event strengthened their resolve to migrate, and they set out for Mecca from Baghdad.

They resided in Mecca for several years when Mr. Ali Akbar Forutan, who later became a Hand of the Cause, informed Mr. Anwar through the secretary of the National Spiritual Assembly of Egypt that the Fada'iyan Islam had prepared a list for the assassination of prominent figures, both political and Bahá'í. Since you reside in Mecca and Islam does not permit non-Muslims to live in the holy land, you must be cautious.

Mr. Anwar recounts that upon receiving this news, I was always waiting to see what fate had in store for my family. Until one day, due to passport renewal, I went from Mecca to Jeddah. I entered the Iranian embassy. As soon as I arrived, the ambassador welcomed me and, after completing the administrative work, stated that a very esteemed guest from Tehran had come to the embassy and wished to visit the Kaaba outside the Hajj season. Since it is not the Hajj season, the embassy cannot do anything.

After much consultation, they told me that you have a special position in Mecca and have many friends, and you can accomplish this task. I was bewildered and stated that performing Hajj outside the Hajj season requires special permission from the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, meaning the King of Saudi Arabia. I don't think I can accomplish this. But the ambassador, who had tried everything and failed to obtain this permission, insisted and emphasized that they were told this task is within your capability. Reluctantly, I asked for two days, but the ambassador stated that the esteemed guest is currently inside the embassy and will accompany you to Mecca. I had no choice; with the esteemed guest, we set out for Mecca by car from Jeddah, and since there was no hotel in Mecca, I took the guest to my home in that unbearable heat.

At the dining table, the esteemed guest kept stroking his beard and saying 'La ilaha illallah.' In Mecca, I spoke with a few of the Mutawwif (those who guide pilgrims during the Hajj season) whom I knew from before, and my wife and I had performed Hajj with them for two years. I sought their help. They said, 'We will arrange this matter, don't worry.' After two days, they informed me that from tomorrow, the Kaaba will be rented in your name for 24 hours. When God's will is attached to something, He provides the means. They had created a legal loophole and paid a nominal rent for renting the Kaaba for 24 hours.

The next morning, with the esteemed guest and two Mutawwif, we set out from the house to the Kaaba. The door of the Kaaba was closed. The Mutawwif handed me the key to open the door. A large number of Pakistani Muslims had gathered around the Kaaba. When the door was opened, we entered the courtyard of the Kaaba. The Pakistanis insisted and pleaded to be allowed to enter the courtyard as well. I asked the Mutawwif, 'What should be done?' They confidently said, 'The house of God is rented to you for 24 hours, and if you wish, you can allow them to enter.' I gladly permitted them to enter.

In the courtyard of the Kaaba, everyone stood for prayer and supplication, but the esteemed and demanding guest requested that the door of the Kaaba be opened so that he could pray and supplicate inside the Kaaba. This matter was also resolved with the approval and guidance of the guides. The door of the House of God was opened, and the esteemed guest and I entered the Kaaba. He immediately stood for prayer, and I, who had never imagined such a blessing in my life and did not wish to pray with the esteemed guest, looked around the House of God and noticed a staircase in a corner that led to the roof of the house.

Considering the words of the guides, I realized that during these 24 hours that the Kaaba is rented to me, I have permission to do anything. I went up the stairs and opened my hands in prayer on the roof of the Kaaba. I thanked the Blessed Beauty that despite my relation to the tribe of Bani Israel, I reached a stage under the shadow of the Bahá'í Faith where the Kaaba of Muslims was rented to me personally for 24 hours, and what the Iranian embassy was unable to do was made possible through the divine confirmations by the servant of the Blessed Beauty. In prayer and supplication, I asked the Blessed Beauty that I am ready for any sacrifice.

After completing the pilgrimage and returning home and enjoying a delicious meal that my wife had kindly prepared, our dear guest kept repeating the phrase 'La ilaha illallah' under his breath and avoided looking at us. We bid him farewell for his journey to Jeddah with good health. I wrote a report of the events to Mr. Foroutan (the secretary of the National Assembly of Iran) and mentioned that until this hour, there has been no news from the representative of the Fadaiyan Islam, and I described the bringing of the embassy guest from Jeddah to Mecca and the rest of the events that occurred, and in conclusion, I expressed my readiness for any incident.

A few months later, Mr. Foroutan wrote to me that the same dear embassy guest was the person responsible for the Fadaiyan Islam who was supposed to assassinate you in Mecca. However, with the facilities that he observed in your possession through divine confirmations, and practically realized that the Iranian embassy was unable to carry it out, he could not accept to commit his heinous act. Therefore, after the pilgrimage, he returned to Iran in a very disturbed and troubled state. Of course, the Fadaiyan Islam created a major problem by assassinating Razmara, the Prime Minister of Iran, and Hojir and several other political figures. That great guest was Mr. Mohammadi Araki, who at the beginning of the Iranian Revolution in 1979, was in charge of the Kayhan and Ettelaat newspapers, and his son was the religious judge of Ahvaz, who issued the order to confiscate my only residential house in Ahvaz, signed by him, and the original order is in my possession. (Photo of the order here)

Mr. Anwar had a very large shop in Sana'a with several sections and was engaged in selling medicine. Of course, household items like pressure cookers and other goods were also sold in this shop. At that time, shops, especially in Sana'a, were not exclusive like today, and it was possible to sell watches in an eyewear shop, for example. Mr. Anwar had four children, three daughters, and one son.

Mr. Nadim Shahidi was the second migrant to arrive in Sana'a. He lived in Sana'a with his wife. Mr. Nadim Shahidi's father was one of the first migrants and residents of Akka and Haifa, and Mr. Nadim was born in Palestine. His wife, Zakieh Khanum Ma'ani, was the daughter of Agha Seyed Ziaollah Ma'ani from the beloved of Hisar and Namagh Khorasan and was among the propagators. His profession was eyewear making, which he learned in Kuwait, and with readiness for migration to Sana'a, Mr. Ziaollah Adlparvar, the dear migrant from Kuwait, provided all kinds of cooperation with him and provided all the initial capital.

I arrived in Sana'a as an apprentice eyewear maker and naturally was his guest for a while until I rented a house. Unfortunately, Mr. Nadim later followed the claim of Mr. Jamshid Ma'ani, his wife's cousin, and after the departure of the beloved from Sana'a, his efforts went unrewarded.

Third, Mr. Soheil Farhadi, the grandson of Mr. Ghabelabadi, the famous propagator of the Cause of God, who had obtained a residence permit as a radio engineer. Fourth, Mr. Dariush Mahmoudi, the brother of the martyr Majid, Mr. Houshang Mahmoudi, who married Miss Farideh, the daughter of Mr. Mohammad Mehdi Mowlavi, a migrant from Aden, a few days before our arrival from India to Aden, and they lived in Mr. Anwar's house in Sana'a and worked in Mr. Anwar's shop. Fifth, Ziaollah Kholousi and Mrs. Mehrangiz Vatankhah. Sixth, Mr. Anoushirvan Torabi from the beloved of Abadan, who had obtained a visa as a barber (due to the unfavorable conditions of barbers in Sana'a). It should be noted that the barber profession in Sana'a was very non-standard in terms of hygiene, and the beloved wanted to contribute to raising hygiene standards by obtaining a visa for him. Mr. Torabi lived with Mr. Soheil Farhadi in a room in Mr. Nadim Shahidi's house.

Mr. Aminollah Zoljalali and his wife, who had obtained a visa as a carpenter, and the family of Mr. Karam Ashnaei from the Bahá'ís of Borazjan, who had obtained a visa as a radio apprentice. Finally, the family of the martyr Majid, Mr. Yadollah Mahmoudnejad, who arrived in Sana'a from Qatar with a young daughter named Taraneh, and the initial adult Bahá'í community in Sana'a gradually grew to sixteen people.

With the Bahá'ís reaching the required number, the first Spiritual Assembly in the city of Sana'a, Yemen, was formed in Ridván 1961. Our joy and happiness from the fruition of the migration and the formation of the Assembly knew no bounds.

Mr. Nadim Shahidi's eyeglass shop in the Shararah area, which was a large square with the Imam of Yemen's palace on one side, had no work for us after opening and cleaning the shop every morning. So, we played chess with some of the locals of Sana'a whom we had become acquainted with. One day, a handsome and dignified young man who was observing our game asked me, 'Are you ready to play with me?' Not knowing him, I simply said, 'Not only will I play, but I am ready to compete with you.' During my time in Dubai, I had learned chess well and was very fond of it. Even in Sana'a, I played with dear Mr. Soheil Farhadi at our home.

In the early days of our marriage, we were playing chess at home with Mr. Soheil Farhadi. My wife said, 'I have put the chicken on the stove, keep an eye on the food. I am going to buy bread.' We said, 'We will pay attention, don't worry.' and continued playing. When my wife returned and opened the door, the house was filled with smoke, and we hadn't noticed. But my wife, with utmost kindness, said, 'It's okay, I'll prepare the food again.' Truly, the patience and magnanimity of women are exemplary. I will never forget her moral virtues.

One day, while we were playing chess, the aforementioned young man came and expressed interest in playing chess. I had previously asked Yemeni friends about this young man. They stated that he was the special aide to the Crown Prince of Yemen and educated in Cairo, Egypt. I realized that he was an important person with a high position. Without paying attention to his rank and position, I played with him very casually, and whenever he lost or was checkmated, I would tease him and joke around. He also behaved the same way whenever he won. In short, we were very close and intimate.

After working in the shop for a few months, I rented an independent house and realized that the salary I received was not enough for daily living expenses and rent. Meanwhile, dear Mehrangiz was also pregnant. Therefore, I suggested to Mr. Nadim Shahidi that I continue as an apprentice optician but not receive a salary, and instead, be allowed to buy some watches from Aden with my own capital, place them in his shop, and sell them to manage my living expenses from the profits. Mr. Shahidi immediately agreed to this proposal.

To procure the watches, I asked Mr. Anwar how they obtained their goods from Aden. Mr. Anwar gave me the address of a person named Haj Hussein Shahari, who procured and sent goods and trade items for them from Aden. Mr. Anwar contacted him and, while introducing me, asked him to fulfill any requests I might have if I contacted him. I first wrote a letter in Arabic, full of spelling mistakes, to that person and requested him to procure thirty Soli brand watches for me. The watches were to be both men's and women's. I also sent him some money. A week later, the watches arrived. One of the small showcases in Mr. Shahidi's shop was allocated to me. It didn't take ten days for all the watches to be sold, and I realized which models were more popular. The second time, I ordered sixty watches, and since most of the buyers were foreign women, mostly Russians and East German nationals, I got to know them and ordered whatever models they wanted.

During this time, I became acquainted with a young Russian girl who ordered several watches at once. I asked her about her job, and she said she was a nurse-midwife working with a professor who had just arrived from Moscow and was collaborating in delivering Yemeni babies at the Sana'a hospital. I asked her to come to our house one day with the professor to meet dear Mehrangiz, who was two months pregnant, to examine her and give any necessary instructions. This way, a very friendly relationship was established between us and the professor and her accompanying nurse. The professor said, 'Since the hospital is very dirty and polluted, it is not necessary for your wife to come to the hospital for delivery. I will come with my colleague to your home and perform the delivery there.' Thus, our first child, named Mitra, was born at home by the Russian professor.

The birth of our first child in Sana'a caused us to encounter difficulties in obtaining a document proving her birth to present to the Iranian embassy in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, which handled consular affairs for Iranians in Yemen. In 1961, those born in Yemen did not have a document or certificate known as 'sijil' or, as they called it, 'mukhallaqa.' Additionally, the child was born at home. With the kindness and assistance of the Russian professor, the child's midwife, I approached the Yemeni Ministry of Foreign Affairs and requested their help. They told me to write whatever I wanted, and they would sign it to send to the Iranian embassy so that the issue of registering our child in the Iranian passport of the parents would be resolved. Since there was no other option, I wrote a sentence with this content, and they signed it and sent it to the embassy in Jeddah. The sentence was:
"The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Mutawakkilite Kingdom of Yemen certifies that the birth of Mitra, daughter of Ziaollah Kholousi, took place in Sana'a."
They signed and stamped it at the bottom and handed it to me.

On the day of Mitra's birth, the ladies of the community provided the utmost cooperation. Especially Mrs. Anwar, who showed all kinds of motherly affection. Our house in Sana'a was not far from the optical shop. In Sana'a, there were two brothers named Nouri and Aouni Ajami, who were apparently descendants of Iranians from the Sassanid era before Islam.

It was written in the history of Yemen that during the reign of Khosrow Anushirvan, the king of Abyssinia attacked Yemen and took the throne from the Yemeni king known as Sayf ibn Dhi Yazan, who then fled. Sayf ibn Dhi Yazan sought refuge at the court of Anushirvan the Just and asked for his help. Khosrow Anushirvan sought a solution from Bozorgmehr, the wise minister, who, not wanting to involve himself in Yemeni affairs, made a significant decision. He gathered all the dangerous prisoners in Iran and told them that they must leave Iran as soldiers accompanying the Yemeni king and participate in the war to help him reclaim his throne. If they succeeded, they could stay in Yemen and live well, but if they failed, they should not return to Iran as they would all be killed. By chance, Sayf ibn Dhi Yazan won and took control of Yemen, and for years until the advent of the Prophet of Islam, Yemen remained a colony of Iran.

When we entered Yemen in 1960, there was a vast province in Yemen called the Province of Iran, which the Yemenis called 'Al-Aryan.' Interestingly, after the Yemeni revolution, the second president of Yemen, named Abdul Rahman Al-Iryani, came to power. In short, the two brothers who had never seen Iran carried the surname Ajami, meaning 'non-Arab foreigner.' I became acquainted with them, and they considered themselves Iranian. Since they had two adjacent houses, they were willing to rent the houses to us Iranians. I rented one house, and Mr. Yadollah Mahmoudnejad rented the second house. And Mitra, my first daughter, was born in this Ajami house.

After a while, I realized that Mrs. Shahidi was upset and complained about me selling watches in her husband's shop because, truthfully, my watch-selling business was more profitable than her husband's optical business. With my commercial acumen, I realized that the climate of Sana'a was very suitable for agriculture, but they did not have good seeds for planting. Therefore, I ordered some red onion seeds, cauliflower, and various tomatoes from India, and since I had an agricultural engineer friend from Palestine, with his help, we sold the improved seeds received from India at a good price, and this trade also brought prosperity to our lives.

Since I did not want to face the displeasure of Mrs. Nadim Shahidi, I suggested to Mr. Shahidi that since the number of Baha'is in Sana'a had exceeded the quorum for an assembly, he should agree to let me go to Taiz and, while establishing an optical shop, also establish the Baha'i community in Taiz. This proposal was agreed upon by Mr. Shahidi and approved by the Sana'a assembly.

Since I did not know the city of Taiz and was the first Iranian to go to that city, it was necessary to obtain letters of introduction from Sana'a for some influential people in Taiz, so that if I encountered any problems upon arrival, they could assist in resolving them. The best person I thought to consult about going to Taiz was my chess-playing friend. He welcomed this idea and, since there was no optician in Taiz, he found this move beneficial for the people of the city and introduced me to the chief of police in Sana'a, who was his friend. He gave me a sealed letter to present to the chief of police in Taiz upon my arrival. To explain, our chess-playing friend, Mr. Abdullah Sallal, was the adjutant to the Crown Prince of Yemen. A few months after we settled in Taiz, he led a revolution against the government and the Imam of Yemen and became the first president of Yemen. Later, I learned that the letter he had the chief of police in Sana'a write to introduce me to the chief of police in Taiz contained praise for me as a harmless and service-oriented individual to the people of Yemen. I realized this after some time living in Taiz and during a meeting with the chief of police in my optician shop.

I entered Taiz alone and, having previous experience, went to the guesthouse. Taiz is a city situated on numerous hills, with houses built atop them. Streets run between the hills. On the main street at the top of a hill, there were a few shops. One of the shops belonged to a barber. To get acquainted and start a conversation, I went to the barber shop and sat in the chair intending to get a haircut and shave. The barber, realizing I was Iranian and wanted to rent a shop in the area for an optician business, offered great cooperation and rented me the shop next to his, which was without a tenant.

I rented a suitable and nice house in the city of Taiz, returned to Sana'a, and with my wife and Mitra, who was about a year old, traveled back to Taiz by car. After settling in the new house, I faced distressing scenes every day. Since it was the early days of the revolution and people were dissatisfied with the previous government officials, every day someone was taken on some pretext and, as they put it, executed in a revolutionary manner. Later, the body was hung from the city gate, and people danced around it. Passersby, having no choice but to pass through the gate, had to witness these horrific and distressing scenes daily and endure them. As these actions were repeated every day and our endurance was at its limit, we vacated the house, which was very good, suitable, large, and comfortable, and began looking for a house near the shop.

There was no suitable house available until one of the shop neighbors said, 'Behind this shop, a lady has a house that she might rent out.' Having searched for a house for several days without success, I took his words as a good omen and immediately went with my wife to the lady's house. We entered the house. The house had only two rooms, one where the landlady lived with her child, and the other was the stable for her donkey, which also became homeless. She rented us her room. Having no other choice, we rented the room.

When we settled in Taiz with the family, the war in Yemen intensified. Since the government had fallen from the Imam of Yemen and a republic had been established, Saudi Arabia supported the deposed government, while Egypt, under Gamal Abdel Nasser, supported the republic, whose president was Mr. Abdullah Sallal, my former chess-playing friend. Several other Arab governments also entered the war to cooperate with both sides. One day, it was announced that two Jordanian pilots, who had flown from Jordan to bomb the city of Sana'a, had defected to the newly established Republic of Yemen with their planes, and the people and government of Yemen celebrated. It was planned that the president himself, accompanied by the two pilots, would visit Taiz as well.

While the president was seated in the middle and each pilot on either side of him on a jeep, with people standing on both sides of the street expressing their emotions, they passed in front of my shop. The barber neighbor and I also came out of the shop to watch the president's and pilots' convoy. Since people were waving their hands, to avoid giving the impression that I was opposed or a foreigner, I also raised my hand to the president. Suddenly, Mr. Abdullah Sallal, seeing me among the crowd, stood up and waved his hand vigorously, expressing his emotions. The situation was such that I did not want the barber friend, who was quite nosy, to realize my acquaintance with the president. I immediately lowered my hand and told him how much the president expressed his emotions for him. He was very pleased.

After some time, as the war and bloodshed in Sana'a intensified due to the revolution and change of government, the friends were forced to evacuate Sana'a. The first family, Mr. Mahmoud Nejad, his wife, and their daughter came to Taiz to leave Yemen. After a while, security issues in Taiz also intensified. By selling the shop, we also left Taiz and headed towards Aden, which was a British colony. Fifty kilometers from Aden was the Sultanate of Lahij, which had its own government separate from Aden but was considered a protectorate of Aden. Since Mr. Sultan of Lahij had an acquaintance and friendship with Mr. Molavi Aziz, all the migrants leaving Yemen, who were not allowed to enter Aden, settled in Lahij. Of course, the Sultan's permission for the Iranian community to reside in Lahij was verbal, and we had no official documents for legal residence. But this prevented the migrants from leaving northern Yemen from straying too far from the area. Perhaps in the near future, when security was restored, we could return to Yemen. Lahij had better weather than Aden and was, in fact, a summer resort for the people of Aden, with many people coming from Aden to Lahij and its surrounding gardens for recreation on Fridays.

During our stay in Taiz, every day with my wife and Mitra, who now walked on her own and had become a very sweet-talking little girl, we would walk on the sloping streets. We would traverse the street and visit the shops inside the city from which we had fled. On the way back, as the uphill street was steep, we would return home by car. Mitra always ran ahead of us, enjoying the steep slope of the street. One day, I noticed she was talking to a Yemeni shopkeeper sitting at his shop door. The shopkeeper, a 25-year-old young man, picked Mitra up and went inside the shop, returning with a doll in the child's hand. We arrived and greeted the young man and thanked him for the doll he had given to the child.

The name of this young man was Mohammad Sharif, and he was indeed a noble man. He had brothers who were all politically active and opposed to the government, but he himself was very sincere and friendly. From the very beginning, a bond formed between us that lasted for years, and with the help of this person, we were able to re-establish the first Bahá'í community in Taiz a few years later.

In Lahij, a person named Abu Bakr Ajami was a friend of the Sultan of Lahij. He also considered himself Iranian, and I spoke a few words with him in Persian. In Lahij, I wanted to establish an optician's shop but couldn't find a suitable store. This same Mr. Abu Bakr built a shop on his land for me and rented it out, and I started the optician business. However, the sale of glasses was very minimal. While I was in Kuwait, I had obtained several addresses of eyewear factories. In Lahij, these addresses proved to be very useful.

One day, I told dear Mehrangiz, who knew English, to write a letter to an Italian company that manufactures eyeglass frames, introducing ourselves and asking them to send us catalogs and samples of their products. After ten days, a letter arrived from that grand company, known as Filus, along with eighty samples of eyeglass frames and fifty models of sunglasses, all free of charge. The content of the letter was such that it seemed as if the company's president had written it to a very close friend. The letter from the company's president stated, 'We are very pleased to get to know you. My wife and I also started our work with a small investment like you. Now I manage the frame manufacturing factory, and my wife is in charge of the sunglasses production factory called Mark Piaw. We are fully prepared to assist in any way we can. We would like to offer you our exclusive agency in Aden and Yemen, and if you wish, in Northeast Africa as well.'

Reading this letter, which dear Mehrangiz translated for me, filled me with a world of hope and gratitude. Gratitude for having such a sincere, pure-hearted, and kind wife who, with a letter written with utmost sincerity and warmth to a large commercial company, prompted such a positive response from them. Of course, all the confirmations were divine, but whatever I say about dear Mehrangiz's sincerity is just a drop in the ocean.

The first family of Bahá'ís in Lahij was Mr. Gholamreza Azimi and Mrs. Rouhi Navaizdan. Mr. Azimi was a young Bahá'í migrant from Saudi Arabia who had gone to Sholapur, India, after me and married Mrs. Rouhi. When we arrived in Lahij, we stayed at their house and rented a place after a few days. Mr. Azimi's profession was dentistry. Mr. Dariush Mahmoudi and Mrs. Farideh had gone from Sana'a to Aden, but since they couldn't obtain residency, they also settled in Lahij. Mr. Yadollah Mahmoud Nejad, who had arrived in Lahij a few days before us from Yemen, also settled there. Additionally, Mr. Soheil Farhadi came from Sana'a to Lahij and settled. Later, Mr. Rahmatollah Hosseini, with whom I had gone from Mashhad to Dubai with the intention of migration, came with his wife from Abu Dhabi to Lahij, and also Mr. Ali Akbar Saleki and his wife, all gathered in Lahij.

Mr. Anwar and his family also arrived in Aden from Sana'a, and since they had Yemeni passports, they were able to obtain residency in Aden. The Bahá'í families in Aden included Mr. Mohammad Mahdi Moulavi and his family, who were the pioneers of Aden, Mr. Abdullah Anwar and his family, Mr. Moji, one of the Seven Imam Muslims who were known in India and Aden as the Bohra community (a sect of the seventy-two Muslim nations) who had been converted to Bahá'í by Mr. Moulavi, but his wife was Muslim. Also, Mr. Tawfiq Saqqaf, who was an Arab from Aden, and his wife was an Iranian Bahá'í. They had met and married in London. Additionally, Mr. Maurice, who was originally French and worked for a large company in Aden, and his wife was Italian and Christian.

The Bahá'ís residing in Lahij, apart from Mr. Azimi and Kholousi, rented a shared shop, and all of them, under the supervision of Mr. Soheil Farhadi, who was fully skilled in radio making, engaged in the noble profession of radio making and managed their lives.

A few months after our arrival in Lahij, our second child, named Fariba, was born in Lahij Hospital. And this same Mr. Abu Bakr Ajami, who had a car, kindly took my wife to the hospital at two-thirty in the morning. We stayed in Lahij for nearly two years until we succeeded in obtaining residency and work permits in Aden. Our financial situation during the first year and a half of our stay in Lahij was very dire.

I remember, Fariba was young and in her childish language asked her mother to throw her a birthday party. To light candles and have a cake. She was a child and not logical, but in her childish world, she greatly benefited from her mother's sincerity and affection. Dear Mehrangiz, who herself was a picture of sincerity, immediately brought a picture from a magazine that had several cakes printed on it, and lit a candle on it. And our dear child was satisfied that a birthday party had been held. The next day we went to Aden. We were guests at Mr. Anwar's house. May God bless Mrs. Anwar, she was like a mother to all the migrants. As soon as Fariba saw her, she said, 'Yesterday was my birthday.' Mrs. Anwar asked, 'Where was your birthday cake?' She said, 'Mom didn't have a cake, she lit a candle on a newspaper cake.' Mrs. Anwar immediately made a very delicious cake and we celebrated Fariba's birthday.

The friends were unaware of our poor financial situation, and since we were always cheerful and smiling, they had no idea that we were suffering financially. During the year and a half, my shop's sales were only sixteen thousand tomans. Towards the end of our stay in Lahij, samples of glasses arrived from Italy. I couldn't sell them in the shop myself, meaning there were no customers. I had to somehow take them to Aden and market them. But every time I went from Lahij to Aden, at the police checkpoint between Lahij and Aden, they would prevent us from entering Aden or cause trouble. And this depended on the officer checking the cars. I had no choice. I had to market the sunglasses in Aden and take orders. Of course, the prices were very cheap, and the eyewear company had announced that from each model, from one piece to a dozen, the price was this much, and the higher the order quantity, the lower the prices.

Moreover, the prices were delivered at the destination, and there were no additional costs for the buyer. If I received an order for a hundred dozen of each model, the final price would be one-tenth of the announced price. They had also considered a 15% sales commission for me. A few days were spent calculating numbers and figures. Since I thought I couldn't get an interesting order in the first stage, I added 15% to the prices myself and took the samples to Aden to get orders.

In Aden, there were only three optical shops, none of which were willing to cooperate and buy optical frames. So, all my efforts and activities were focused on sunglasses. Since the sun was intense in Aden, most shops sold sunglasses. Sunglasses were not exclusive like optical glasses. In one day, I received a very good order from merchants. First, I would tell them to see the prices and models. Choose any model you want. No money will be taken from you for this order. When the goods arrive, I will bring and deliver them and receive the price. The merchants, who didn't know me, would give a high order under these conditions. After a week, I realized that the demand for sunglasses was such that if I delayed in ordering, the company might not be able to send all the ordered goods immediately. So, without considering the consequences, I sent all the received orders to the company.

Exactly 25 days after sending the order, I was sitting in the shop when I saw a young Englishman enter the shop and ask for my name. He knew a little Arabic, and I knew a little English. Finally, I understood that he was saying, 'I am the manager of the National Grand Lease branch of the English bank in Lahij, and your order has arrived from Italy. The company had asked the bank about your account activity. Although there was no activity in my account and I had only opened an account, the bank manager gave a positive response. He said, 'All your orders are now in Lahij inside the bank building. Here are the invoices, you must come and pay the money and receive your goods.' It should be explained that since Aden was a free port, no customs duties were applied to imported goods.

I took the invoices from him and asked for a deadline until tomorrow because I had to prepare the money. I immediately took a car and headed to Aden. I went directly to dear Mr. Anwar and since he had also ordered some glasses, I explained the situation. He advised me to tell the bank manager that you cannot clear all the goods at once, and if he agreed, with several clearances, you would be able to prepare the money and not become a bad account with the bank. I said the first order belongs to you, it is ready. I must deliver the goods. Our agreement was that I would bring the goods and take the money, but now I have no money. If you kindly give me the money for your order, maybe I can implement your suggestion and clear part of the invoice, gain the bank manager's approval, and deliver the rest in the same way to their owners.

Mr. Anwar agreed. He gave the amount for his ordered goods. I took the money and happily returned to Lahij and went to the bank in the morning and asked the bank manager, who was the same young man from yesterday, to clear the goods in several parts. The bank, which was no more than a four-by-five room, was full of my ordered cartons. Despite this, the bank manager showed the utmost kindness. I gave him the money received from Mr. Anwar. He also delivered twice Mr. Anwar's order to me. I took Mr. Anwar's order and gave the extra cleared amount to another merchant who had ordered, and with the receipt of his order amount, the issue was resolved.

With the 15% price increase that I had initially added to the prices and the 15% company commission, I was left with more than fifty dozen sunglasses of various models as profit. A few days later, when I was going to Aden to sell my sunglasses, I met a very tall and robust man wearing Yemeni clothes inside the car. During the conversation, he asked me which country I was from. I introduced myself, and since I trusted him, I said that my work is in optics and I would like to establish an optical shop in Aden. I even told him that I am willing to partner with a good Yemeni Arab citizen if he knows someone, to succeed in establishing the shop.

I also mentioned that my eyewear manufacturing would be different from the existing ones in Aden because I could grind and produce lenses myself. He found this interesting and promised to assist me, giving me an address to visit him the next time I went to Aden. A few days passed, and I went from Lahij to Aden and visited the address he had given me. It was the address of the Shell Oil Company. The company guard asked for the name of the person I was meeting. I said Mr. Bamataraf had given me this address.

The guard, looking at my height and size with suspicion and reluctance, accompanied me, and we went to the second floor of the building. He knocked on a door to get permission from the secretary to enter. The office seemed very elegant, clean, and large to me. I saw the person I had met in the car between Lahij and Aden sitting behind a very large desk in a tidy suit with a tie. As soon as he saw me, he stood up from his chair, welcomed me, shook my hand, and seated me beside him. The guard, who did not expect this, immediately left the room. After the usual pleasantries, he asked me, "What can I do for you?"

I said, "The first and most important step is obtaining residency in Aden, and if you can introduce me to the immigration office so that I can get residency, it would be a very important action." I realized he was one of the senior officials of the Shell Oil Company. He comfortably stated, "I know the head of the immigration office. I have time now if you would like to visit him together and discuss the matter." I did not expect such a positive and immediate reaction, especially during his official working hours.

We went to the Aden immigration office in his car. After introducing ourselves to the office staff, we requested a meeting with the head of the immigration office. The two of us, guided by the immigration office staff, reached the head's presence. Mr. Bamataraf greeted and chatted with the head and brought up my eyewear manufacturing matter. The head of the immigration office told Mr. Bamataraf, "Please wait outside the room while I speak with this young man." He very respectfully escorted Mr. Bamataraf out of the room.

He asked me, "Have you lived in Aden before?" I said, "No." He asked, "Do you know anyone in Aden who can vouch for you?" I replied, "No." He asked, "Are you willing to partner with a Yemeni person?" My answer was positive. After asking this question, I thought maybe he wanted to become a partner himself. I said, "I am even willing to partner with you, as you are a respectable person." He laughed. After a few more questions, I told him the truth. I said, "I am a Bahá'í. I wish to reside in Aden. With the work I know, I can both make a living and serve the people." I told him, "I am not political at all. Do not worry about my being Iranian."

He, being a mature man of about fifty-eight years old, was very excited and delighted by the honesty of my words and perhaps my appearance, which showed that I was answering his questions with utmost sincerity. He introduced himself. He said, "I have been a teacher for years, and my knowledge of anthropology is complete. It has been only two years since I was transferred to this immigration office. I am originally of Indian descent, but we have been in Aden for several generations." After the British colonized Aden, they employed many Indian staff, resulting in a generation of Indian-Yemeni descent in Aden.

In summary, he said, "I have a Yemeni student who told me that if a trustworthy person comes to your office wanting to establish a public-benefit institution in Aden, with the knowledge I have of your good judgment, if you deem it appropriate, inform me. I am willing to invest in that work." He further explained, "This student of mine is currently in the currency exchange business and is establishing the first casino in Aden. He is a very beneficial man and loves his country immensely, doing everything in his power for its prosperity." It was decided that I would return in a week to receive an answer. The family name of this angelic teacher and head of the immigration office was Mr. Ibrahim Laghman.

When saying goodbye, he told me, "Young man, stay away from Mr. Bamataraf." I was surprised. We left the immigration office with Mr. Bamataraf. I wanted to return to Lahij immediately and share this joyful news with my wife. Mr. Bamataraf asked, "Your conversation with the head of the immigration office took a long time." He wanted to understand what had transpired. I said, "We talked a lot, and Mr. Ibrahim Laghman asked many questions and finally said to return in two weeks for an answer." Mr. Bamataraf, wanting to know what had happened between Mr. Ibrahim Laghman and me and realizing I was not willing to recount the entire conversation, said, "Let's go to a restaurant and have a beer." I said, "I don't drink beer." He said, "You don't drink, but I will."

I realized that I had no choice but to agree. We entered the restaurant. He ordered beer. I ordered Pepsi. In the span of an hour, he drank more than seven half-liter bottles of beer. With my eyes wide open, I said, 'My time is up, and my wife will be worried. I must return to Lahij immediately.' I went to the restaurant cashier and paid for the drinks. While settling the bill with the cashier, Mr. Bamterf ordered an eighth bottle of beer. I paid for everything. I told the cashier, 'If he orders more beer after I leave, take the money from him,' and I quickly left the restaurant.

On the way back from Lahij to Aden, I recalled the events of that day. As Mr. Ayadi Amrullah Abul-Qasim Faizi said, 'Soldiers you do not see,' meaning divine confirmations were strongly upon us. I gave my wife a full report of the day's trip to Aden, and we both offered prayers of gratitude, hoping for a swift resolution. That night, my dear Mehrangiz had a dream, which she recounted the next morning.

'I dreamed that in a vast desert, Abdu'l-Bahá was sitting on a cylindrical stone like a chair, and I was sitting between his legs. Two of my other sisters were sitting, one on the right and the other on the left. Abdu'l-Bahá was reciting prayers and gently stroking my hair with his hand. I woke up from the dream.' My interpretation of my wife's dream was that, God willing, we would be successful in our migration. However, this dream took a long time to manifest, and its outcome appeared after we were expelled from Aden and settled in Iran, which will be detailed during our stay in Iran.

A week later, I went to Aden to meet Mr. Ibrahim Luqman and receive the outcome of his discussions with the person who was supposed to become my partner. After greetings and expressing happiness at my timely visit, Mr. Ibrahim Luqman said, 'The name of my student is Radman Saeed Abdulrahman. He is a successful, patriotic, trustworthy, and honest young man. You should visit him at this address, and with the discussions you will have, God willing, you will reach an agreement. If you reach an agreement, he will take full responsibility for obtaining residency for you and your family and any administrative and governmental matters you may have in Aden.'

I took Mr. Radman Saeed Abdulrahman's address and went to the Tawahi area, where the Aden port was located. Mr. Radman's shop was a small currency exchange that did not seem very successful at first glance. After greeting and introducing myself, mentioning that Mr. Ibrahim Luqman, the head of the immigration office, had given me his address, he gave me a warm welcome. He added in his introduction that his currency exchange business was conducted inside passenger ships passing through Aden. Therefore, he did not need a large office. He explained that approximately 400 to 450 passenger ships passed through Aden each month, traveling from the Far East to Europe and from Europe to the Far East, the Middle East, and occasionally the eastern coasts of Africa. With the permission he had, he was responsible for all currency exchanges for passengers, and thankfully, he had a very good income. However, since he had a Somali partner, he was interested in personally partnering with me in the eyewear business. Perhaps one of his brothers could also help in the shop.

It should be explained that during those years, between 1963 and 1964, Aden was a free and very prosperous port commercially, while it was a British colony. He also mentioned that he was busy establishing the first casino in Aden. After an hour of conversation, it was concluded that he would see an experienced lawyer to draft a partnership agreement and include the parties' demands in it. I told him my demands were limited. Write whatever you want, but you will not have the right to interfere in the internal affairs of the shop. Secondly, obtaining residency and any legal issues outside the shop that may arise for us will be your responsibility. He agreed.

I told him that I needed to go to India to procure lens grinding machines and bring them to Aden. During my trip to India, you must secure a shop in the Ma'alla area, which is the English-speaking area of Aden, and complete the showcases and carpentry work to be ready for opening upon my return. Regarding the initial partnership capital, it was decided to make a decision after returning from India. With the approval and guidance of Mr. Ibrahim Luqman, both of us showed very favorable opinions towards each other.

I spent a few days selling sunglasses and researching the cheapest ship traveling from Aden to Bombay. I also wrote a letter to Mr. Vatankhah, my dear wife's father, informing him that we were heading to India to see them and purchase eyewear machinery. I asked if they could assist if there was a shortage of funds for the machinery. His response was very joyful, encouraging, and reassuring.

We were supposed to visit my wife's family for the first time in three years with our two children. Instead of taking cash to buy the machinery, I prepared a tape recorder, a camera, and some other items that I knew would sell well in Bombay and were customs-free. At that time, since Aden was a free port, the price difference with India was more than fifty percent. Finally, we bought a ticket for a French ship named Laos, which was headed to Vietnam and had a stop in Bombay. Since the journey took seven days and nights, the ticket included meals and a room. It was a big ship, but no words can describe the filth and the bad quality of the food.

Our room was on the second floor of the ship. They brought us meals three times a day. Considering that when I booked the ticket, I had specified that the room should have European meals, but we were served Chinese and Vietnamese food. Especially lunch, which was pig's feet every day—a very smelly and bad-tasting dish. Our entertainment was throwing this inedible food into the sea and watching the sea creatures attack to devour it.

We embarked on the journey. After several days and nights, they finally announced that the ship would first go to the port of Karachi. I told my wife and children, who were fed up with the bad food, that a few years ago when I was going to India, I stopped in Karachi and knew some Bahá'í friends who have a famous restaurant there. We will go there and make up for the hunger of these past few days. The ship anchored at the port of Karachi and announced that it would stay for 16 hours, and any passengers who wanted to tour the city could disembark.

We quickly disembarked and made our way to the Ahba restaurant in Karachi. In the spacious restaurant, they had made small rooms for families. We quickly entered one of the rooms. The Ahba restaurant in the Saddar area of Karachi belonged to the Zoroastrian-descended Bahá'ís from Yazd. They had very diverse, interesting, and delicious foods. We renewed our order several times. Mitra and Fariba usually didn't eat much, but we couldn't get enough of the food.

Finally, after two hours of eating and resting, I went to the restaurant cashier to pay for the food. The cashier stood up and loudly said 'Allah-u-Abha.' He was Mr. Fereydoun Yazdi Midi, the secretary of the National Assembly of Pakistan. I stood there bewildered, as I had neither seen nor known him. With a smile, he said, 'You are Mr. Ziaollah Kholousi, the son-in-law of Mr. Bahram Vatankhah, aren't you?' My dear Mehrangiz, who knew him a little, introduced our two children with the greeting 'Allah-u-Abha.' He said, 'Your marriage has crossed the borders of India and reached Pakistan. It was a very interesting and controversial marriage, unique in its kind. It has changed all the usual formulas in India and Pakistan.' In short, he showed a lot of kindness and affection. No matter how much I insisted on paying for the food, he didn't accept. He said, 'You entered the family room so quickly that there was no chance for greetings and handshakes.' I was so embarrassed. If I had met him before sitting at the table, I wouldn't have ordered so much food. Then we went into the city of Karachi and visited some Bahá'í friends in Pakistan whom we knew from before.

After leaving Karachi, the ship anchored at the port of Bombay after thirty-six hours. Mr. Vatankhah and his wife had come from Sholapur to Bombay to welcome us. The children, who were seeing their beloved grandparents for the first time, showed their happiness by constantly hugging them. I was so happy for my dear Mehrangiz, who after more than three years, was able to see her parents, that I couldn't contain myself. In short, I, who didn't think I would be able to return to India and visit my wife's family for another ten years, was very happy and proud.

We spent a few days traveling to Pune, Panchgani, and Sholapur and visiting dear friends. Since the factory manufacturing the optical machinery was located in central India, in the city of Indore near Delhi, we left our dear daughters with their grandmother and traveled to Indore by train with Mrs. Mehrangiz. Of course, I had obtained the company's address while staying in Kuwait from Mr. Hassan Saadat, in whose shop I was learning optical work.

The heads of the machinery manufacturing company realized that almost all the optical businesses in the Persian Gulf and Arabia at that time were Bahá'í, and they all had very good relations with each other. So much so that I had obtained their address from Kuwait, and with the background they had in trading with Kuwait and Bahá'í friends, and with the skilled translator who was with me (dear Mehrangiz) explaining the issues in their language, they treated us very well and offered very low prices. Since I mentioned that I intended to expand the shop in the future, the prices were so reasonable that I didn't need to borrow from Mr. Vatankhah. It was agreed that the purchased machinery would be sent to our address in Aden by ship within a week.

It was very interesting. Confirmation from heaven and earth was included. After a month of staying and touring in India, we returned to Aden on a large ship that was heading to Europe from Bombay. Our dear partner had rented a shop of about thirty square meters in the Ma'alla area, and the carpenter had completed the showcases according to the plan I had given him earlier. The partnership contract was also written and waiting for my signature. In Bombay, I also prepared some raw lenses and materials needed for grinding lenses and frames and brought them with me to Aden.

I clearly remember that on Thursday, we cleaned the shop and placed a few frames, sunglasses, and photos we had in the showcases when a few English ladies entered the shop. They expressed great satisfaction with the establishment of the eyewear shop in the Ma'alla area, the English-speaking area. Dear Mehrangiz, who was my companion and helper in all matters and was helping clean the shop at that time, started talking to the English ladies and introduced the shop's work. They were very welcoming to the presence of an English-speaking lady in the shop.

Before traveling to India, I informed the company Philos, which had previously sent me samples of very interesting and lightweight optical frames in various designs, that, thank God, I had obtained residency in Aden and, God willing, would open the shop. I had requested them to send me two pieces of each model they had immediately. I also told them to inform the Piaw company, which produces sunglasses, that I would need sunglasses as well. These two companies collectively sent nearly 400 frames and sunglasses as samples and without charging a price, via sea mail to my address in Aden.

It is worth mentioning that I had not received the 15% commission that the Philos company had considered for me the first time. In short, the post office informed me that a package had arrived from Italy in my name. Please visit to receive it. We had scheduled the shop's opening for Monday and had announced it. Interestingly, the sample packages from the Philos and Piaw companies were received from the post office on Sunday, and the shop was fully arranged overnight and opened on Monday morning.

Mr. Redman and many of his friends, who were from all walks of life, also came. I realized how popular my partner was among the people. Additionally, his casino was to open in a few days. The reception from English families was very strange and interesting. Each of them ordered three pairs of glasses instead of one. Finally, one day I asked Mehrangiz to inquire from the English ladies about this eagerness to buy glasses. The answer was very interesting. They replied, 'We have National Health in England, but the insurance company's frames are all round and in the style of Mahatma Gandhi's era. Frames and glasses in England are much more expensive than in Aden. Instead of buying one pair of glasses in London, we can buy three pairs in Aden for the same price.'

The work in the eyewear shop started with such intensity that it was beyond the capacity of one person to manage. Therefore, I hired a local worker who was a very good-natured but slow and lazy man. I taught him how to grind lenses, and I prepared all the tools and gave him the lenses to semi-grind, and I completed the work with other machines. Nearly fifty lenses had to be ground daily for 25 pairs of glasses. I had also ordered plenty of ready lenses from England. In other words, there was no prescription in Aden that our shop could not fulfill. I also established very good relations with other optical shops in Aden. If they had any problems in terms of supplying the lenses they needed, I would help them amicably if I could. In short, our eyewear business was as busy as a bakery. In the evenings, when people came to pick up their glasses, they had to stand in line.

Despite having advanced and up-to-date machines, the workload was so much that I would go to the shop at five in the morning and, if I didn't have to leave the shop at noon to bring the children from school, I would work in the shop until eleven at night. One afternoon when the shop was very crowded, a young Arab man handed me his receipt for his glasses. Usually, the shop's policy was that the total price, the amount received, and the balance were noted on the customer's slip, and the same story was noted in the envelope containing the customer's glasses, along with the individual's prescription. I gave him the glasses and was talking to another customer who was in a hurry. The young man took advantage of the situation and left the shop without paying the remaining balance for the glasses. I reminded him that he hadn't paid the rest of his glasses' price. Embarrassed in front of the other customers, he brazenly claimed that he had paid the rest. I repeated two or three times that he hadn't paid, and he insisted that he had given a hundred shillings and even claimed that he should get the rest back. All the customers were watching. To end the matter, I said, 'Is this lady seller standing next to me acceptable to you?' He said, 'Yes.' I said, 'I will ask her, if she says you have paid, I will return the rest to you with an apology.' With utter shamelessness, he said, 'I agree.' I turned to dear Mehrangiz and asked her, 'Did you see this gentleman give me any money after receiving his glasses?' Mehrangiz replied, 'Yes, this young man paid.' Knowing as clear as daylight that he hadn't paid, I apologized to the brazen young man and returned the rest of the money he claimed, and the matter was resolved. In fact, he took the glasses for free and without any cost.

It was not acceptable to me at all. The shop never got quiet enough for me to ask dear Mehrangiz the reason for her wrong judgment. Finally, that night we went home at ten. I asked, 'Did he really give me money?' With complete honesty, she said, 'No, he didn't give any money at all. But during the argument, I realized he was saying he had given a hundred shillings. Your cash register was full of hundred shillings. In this crowded shop with so many people inside, you would have had to close the shop and go to the police station to file a complaint. This young Arab and Yemeni might have been in need. You couldn't have won. It's better that with a hundred shillings, you made a heart happy and ended the trouble. That's why I judged that he had paid. Don't you feel at peace now?' I became more aware of Mehrangiz's correct judgment and timely decision and her not arguing with an ignorant person, which was one of the outstanding moral virtues of this noble lady.

The Spiritual Assembly of Aden was formed. The members of the assembly included Mr. Mohammad Mehdi Molavi, Mr. Abdullah Anwar, Mr. Soheil Farhadi, Mr. Dariush Mahmoudi, Mr. Heshmatollah Sabet Sharghi, Mr. Mouji, Mr. Tawfiq Thaqaf, Mr. Maurice, and Ziaollah Kholousi. Of course, between the years 1963 and 1967, the number of migrants coming to Aden increased. One of these individuals was Mr. Enayatollah Shirazi, who had an eyeglass-making business in Tehran and had expressed his readiness to migrate to Aden. With the help of Mr. Radman, my partner, we managed to arrange residency in Aden for him and due to the high workload, we also made him a partner. Other dear migrants entered Aden and Lahij with many difficulties, such as Mr. Ziaollah Pourahmari, who married the sister of Mr. Azimi's wife, who had come from India, in Lahij. Mr. Moein Moshfeghi, Mr. Shafiei, and Mr. Rezaei with their families, and Mr. Bahman Moghaddas and other dear ones, each of whom, for various reasons, could not establish a business and settle in Aden and Lahij, but now as I write these lines, all are successful and proud in the world of migration and service. Sessions and classes for increasing knowledge of the Faith were also held. Even Mr. Eshraq Khavari came to Aden from the Emirates for a few days. We were always thinking that if possible, we should prepare more migrants for migration to North Yemen. North Yemen was gradually becoming secure, but in Aden, whispers of independence were heard, and insecurity and revolutionary operations were infiltrating from north to south.

Mohammad Sharif, who had become acquainted with me in Taiz through Mitra, our young child, came to the shop one day and expressed that if such a shop were opened in Taiz, meaning North Yemen, people would welcome it well. I told him if you promise to obtain residency for one of the Iranian children, I am ready to introduce someone who knows eyeglass-making to you for Taiz so that you can partner and start working there.

To ensure he understood the work process and high sales of the shop, I told him you can work in our shop for fifteen days starting today. He gladly accepted and did an apprenticeship for fifteen days. After fifteen days, he happily promised that he would immediately take steps to obtain a visa for an Iranian individual. We also informed the friends in Qatar and Kuwait that any of the migrants who know eyeglass-making and are willing to migrate to North Yemen (Taiz) should send their documents.

Mr. Engineer Sasani, a young bachelor from the friends in Tehran who had migrated to Qatar and married the family of Mr. Akhtari, migrants from Yazd to Qatar, and whose field of study was soil science engineering, expressed his readiness. However, he did not have much information in the field of eyeglass-making. Mr. Mohammad Sharif informed me that the visa was ready. I sent him the name and passport number of Mr. Engineer Sasani, which had been sent to me, so that he could arrange the necessary visa.

Since migrants had to go to North Yemen via Aden, Mr. Engineer Sasani arrived in Aden alone and learned the complete training in our shop, including lens grinding for eyeglass prescriptions, over a month. Mohammad Sharif came to Aden and went to Taiz with Mr. Engineer Sasani. They also established a shop and became very successful, even establishing a branch of their shop in Sana'a. Unfortunately, four years later, Mr. Engineer Sasani, during a trip to India, passed away due to a surgical operation because of an allergy to anesthesia. However, Mohammad Sharif continued to pay the share of Mr. Sasani's family from the shop's income for a long time.

From 1967, two parties in Aden were competing for independence and at the same time were engaged with the British army. To the extent that killing and assassinating people had become normal and routine, and it could be said that security had vanished from society. One day, while walking on Ma'alla Street, an Arab youth shot the bank manager, who was a young Englishman, with a pistol and fled. Security had become very difficult. The families of the British soldiers who lived along the main Ma'alla Street had no peace. Revolutionaries came into Ma'alla Street and fired RPGs at the homes of the families of British soldiers.

Between every few blocks of buildings, there was an alley to the back street where Arab and Indian families lived. Since security had been taken away from the families of British soldiers, all these alleys were blocked with concrete blocks to prevent passage from the main street to the side streets. Our shop and home were located on the main Ma'alla Street where the residential homes of the British soldiers' families were. Therefore, at night from nine o'clock, the street was almost under martial law, and with the deployment of British soldiers to protect the families' security, working for me until eleven at night was not without danger and problems, but I had no choice and continued. Every night when I left the shop intending to go home, I would meet a new soldier, and they also tolerated my presence.

I remember that due to the insecurity and explosions that occasionally occurred on the street or in parked cars on the street's edge, it was decided that Faith-related meetings like the Feast should be held in the afternoons so that we could be home before nine at night. One night when we had a Feast that ended around six-thirty, since there was time until nine, the family friends decided to take a short walk with the children and then everyone would go home with their own means.

After ten minutes of walking on the left side of the street, a white car with several young Arabs inside, thinking that English families were walking, threw a bomb towards us from the right side of the boulevard. Our luck was that at the moment the bomb was thrown, we were behind parked cars on the side of the street saying our goodbyes. This time, too, we were strongly confirmed, and after the bomb exploded, several shrapnel pieces from the bomb lodged into the calf muscle of Mr. Soheil Farhadi, causing him pain for a long time. On the advice of the doctors, they decided against surgery to remove the shrapnel because it would require cutting the muscle.

The doctors had stated that after a while, the muscle itself would form a protective layer around the shrapnel. Interestingly, our little daughter, Fariba, was not spared from the bomb's shrapnel either. Since she was crying and restless, after a physical inspection, I noticed that a large part of the child's right thigh was severely bruised. It turned out that a piece of the bomb's shrapnel, after cooling down, had hit the child's body hard.

After the bomb explosion and the crowd of people, the police patrol also arrived and requested explanations from the witnesses at the scene, including us, who were slightly hit. Dear Mehrangiz Khanum, who apparently saw the whole scene and the throwing from the white car, reported her observations to the police. Since we were all worried about Mr. Farhadi's leg and our child's restlessness, it was decided that for further investigation, the next day, the police would visit the shop and prepare a written report with Mehrangiz Khanum's observations.

That same night, the incident of the bomb being thrown at Iranian families was broadcast on Aden radio. We returned home. At 8 in the morning, Mr. Radman, my partner, came to the shop. He was very upset and agitated and said, 'What did your wife see that she told the police?' I asked him, 'How do you know that my wife made statements to the police?' He said, 'Kholousi dear, I have friends in both the English circles and the police and all the organizations. And if you remember, I am responsible for protecting you and your family.'

Early in the morning, police friends told me, 'Your partner's wife made important statements about the vehicle carrying several revolutionaries and the manner of the bomb throwing, and in two hours, the police and English experts will come to the optical shop for a complete investigation of your partner's wife. And he stated that I am not against your honesty, but this honesty in this situation is not fundamentally beneficial for your family and even for me, who is your partner. If you insist, your shop and family will be destroyed. I asked, 'What should be done?'

He said my police friends recommended that you ask your partner's wife to tell the police experts who will come for the investigation that my statements last night were out of fear and concern for my child's life being in danger, and later when I thought about it, I realized that all those statements were nothing but illusions. Deny seeing the car and the bomb throwing and other statements, and in this way, save yourself and your family from future troubles that the revolutionaries will create for you.

He also said they told me that the revolutionaries have no enmity with Iranians and, through me, express their embarrassment for the act they committed. I gave him my assurance. He left, and it took an hour for the police and English experts to arrive. During this time, I spent it guiding and convincing dear Mehrangiz Khanum to say and express something she was not at all willing to say.

The security situation in Aden had severely deteriorated, and several friends from North Yemen went to Iran. Even our family had to send our two little daughters by plane to India to their grandmother. After a while, when the situation slightly improved, we brought them back to Aden with us, and they continued their studies as before at the Catholic Christian school in Aden. The memories of this period were very instructive and numerous and became a way for us to advance our life experiences in the future.

One day, while driving, I passed through an intersection when the traffic light was yellow. The traffic police ordered me to stop and stated, "Why did you pass when the light was red?" I told him, "When I reached the middle of the intersection, the light was yellow, and it turned red by the time I passed through." However, the police did not pay attention and issued a citation, saying that I must appear in court in 15 days for the judge to decide on my fine. I had no choice, so I took the police's letter and, after 15 days, closed the shop and went to the address they had given.

After a long wait and half a day had passed, it was finally my turn. According to the English laws still in effect in Aden, after entering the room where defendants were placed to confess their crimes, the judge asked without any question: "Are you guilty?" I said, "No." The honorable judge said I should return in 15 days. When I told my partner about the situation, he laughed and said, "You should have told the judge you were guilty and paid the fine to get out. Now you will have to repeat this story several more times and, in the end, still pay the fine."

When I closed the shop again after fifteen days and went to court and heard the same questions, I decided to end this story. The question was repeated like the first time, "Are you guilty?" I told the honorable judge, "I, my father, and my grandfather are all guilty!" The judge, faced with this unusual situation, asked, "Are you insane?" I said, "Yes!" and the judge ordered the police to collect a ten-toman fine from me and expel me from the court.

During this period, as the security situation in Aden worsened day by day, the only immigrant from the island of Socotra arrived in Aden by dhow. Socotra is an island in the Indian Ocean and part of Yemen's territorial geography, located near Hadhramaut. Hadhramaut is one of Yemen's eastern provinces and was one of the sultanates around Aden, administered under British supervision. This island was one of the points that had to be conquered in the ten-year plan. Mr. Kamali Sarvestani was the first immigrant who, at the beginning of the ten-year plan, succeeded in conquering this island, and his name was recorded in the golden tablet by the beloved Guardian of the Cause of God. The second immigrant was a young man from Sarvestan named Mr. Heshmatollah Sabet Sarvestani, who settled on this island after Mr. Kamali.

The climate of this island is more similar to the atmosphere of the African continent. The plants on the island were also African samples. The island's connection to the outside world was almost cut off for six months of the year due to the strong ocean winds.
