In this security turmoil in Aden, Mr. Heshmatollah Sabet Sarvestani came to Aden with a dhow from Socotra to procure essential supplies. Most of the island's people were engaged in pearl fishing. When Mr. Sarvestani intended to return to the island of Socotra, he was denied entry, and as a result, all his life and assets in Socotra were either confiscated or lost, and he remained stranded in Aden.

I, who always viewed life from a positive perspective, jokingly told him that now is the time for you to get married. This verbal and fleeting joke gradually became a reality. After opening an optician shop in Aden, one of the people's requests was eye testing and determining the prescription for glasses. Initially, through a connection my partner established with an eye doctor at the British soldiers' hospital, it was agreed that the doctor would examine the eyes of those we referred to him, in addition to sending prescriptions for the soldiers and their families. The British soldiers' eye hospital in Aden was dedicated to British families and did not accept other patients.

At the beginning of establishing the optician shop in Aden, I contacted my wife's sister and brother in India and suggested that they immediately enroll in the optometry school in Hyderabad Deccan and complete the two-year optometry college course to prepare for migration to Aden. They followed my suggestion, and after obtaining their optometry degrees, my wife's sister migrated to Aden and her brother to Somalia, and both were very well received.

At the time of Mr. Heshmatollah Sabet Sarvestani's arrival, the dear immigrant from Socotra to Aden, my wife's sister was working in our shop as an optometrist. With the cooperation and assistance of other friends, Mr. Sarvestani and Ms. Tabandeh Vatan Khah got married in Aden. Although they endured numerous difficulties on the path of migration, ultimately, after years of residence, they were expelled from North Yemen, and for a time, Mr. Heshmatollah Sabet Sarvestani disappeared, and the family had no information about his whereabouts, which was apparently one of the prisons in Aden. Now, with successful children in Muscat, the Emirates, and recently Iceland, they have finally settled in Luxembourg, Europe, after being expelled from Yemen, and all are successful and confirmed.

With the rumors of possible independence and the departure of the British from Aden, the intensity of the revolutionaries' attacks increased day by day. In Aden, there were two popular parties competing for power after independence. One was called the National Party and the other the Communist Party. Every day, the strikes became more widespread until one day it was announced that due to a strike, transportation would stop in one hour.

Drivers hurried home with their vehicles to avoid being on the streets when the strike began. One day at noon, Mr. Shirazi, our partner, waited in vain for a vehicle to take him home. Two weeks before this incident, my partner Redman told me, 'One of the English officers, due to an urgent trip, is selling a very good car that has only been driven a thousand kilometers. If I am interested, he can buy it for me. The price of the car was only ten thousand tomans, and it was an MG brand car. But I didn't know how to drive. Anyway, I agreed and bought the car.

A few minutes before the strike was announced, dear Mehrangiz insisted that I take Mr. Shirazi, who couldn't find any transport to take him home, to his house and return before the strike began. I complied and set off with Mr. Shirazi from the Ma'alla area to the Crater area where his house was. I dropped off Mr. Shirazi and wanted to return to the shop when the strike started.

The revolutionaries were blocking the streets by placing buses across them, preventing cars from passing. I asked one of the revolutionaries, who seemed familiar to me, to allow me to continue on my way home since I was only ten minutes away. He said there was no problem, but in two minutes, we all have orders to shoot at any vehicle, and it's better for you not to take the risk, abandon your car, and find shelter for yourself.

Since Mr. Moulavi's house was closer than Mr. Shirazi's, I parked the car and took refuge in Mr. Moulavi's house, which was on the third floor of a building overlooking the main street. As the strike began, so did the shooting. It seemed the revolutionaries had colluded with the local police and had taken refuge in the police station opposite Mr. Moulavi's house, exchanging fire with the British soldiers stationed on the hill behind Mr. Moulavi's house.

Inside Mr. Moulavi's house, I stood behind a column and could see both the street and the gunfire. I noticed two tanks had stopped in front of the house on the street, and several British soldiers disembarked to prepare for an attack on the police station held by the revolutionaries. But right before my eyes, two soldiers were shot from inside the houses, and the tanks fled the area by overturning the buses parked across the street.

The exchange of fire continued for fifteen hours, and the bodies of the soldiers remained in the street. The next day, around eleven in the morning, when calm had returned, I came down from Mr. Moulavi's house to go to my own home, but I realized that during the exchange of fire, the windshield and radiator of the car had been hit, and the car needed to be taken to a repair shop.

In short, for three days and nights, the connection between Ma'alla and Crater, which wasn't far apart, was cut off due to the damaged streets and the risk of gunfire, and since we had no phone or other means of communication, my wife and I were unaware of each other's fate.

The first action after going home was to contact my partner and recount the story. He said, 'Don't worry, the Benz company representative is responsible for repairing MG cars, and I will arrange for your car to be repaired.' The car was transferred to the Mercedes-Benz repair shop and was supposed to be ready within a month.

I told my partner that it would be appropriate to take a few days' trip to Iran and stay away from the strikes in Aden. He also said that since Mr. Shirazi is busy working in the shop, it is the best time for your trip. We traveled with the family via Kuwait to Tehran and then to Mashhad, and for the first time in twelve years, I was able to visit my dear family in Mashhad. Over time, my brother in Mashhad had managed to buy my military exemption for one hundred tomans, the currency of that day, and of course, we greatly enjoyed seeing our mother, brothers, and dear relatives, especially since the mother, brothers, and their wives warmly welcomed the Indian bride and grandchildren.

A few days after our arrival in Iran, I received a letter from Mr. Shirazi informing me that the revolutionaries had attacked the Mercedes-Benz repair shop and stolen several Benz cars, including my car which had been repaired and was ready for delivery. They sought guidance on what to do. I thought to myself that the deed was done, and under the current circumstances, the best course of action was to enjoy the trip and the company of my mother, brothers, and friends. Losing the car should not spoil this happiness.

We stayed in Iran for a while and, with a very high and hopeful spirit after visiting friends and acquaintances, returned to Aden. I talked to my partner about the car. My partner had many friends among the revolutionaries. He promised to investigate and inform me of the results. A few days passed, and he reported that your car is in the possession of a sergeant from the army. He said he could retrieve the car from him and return it to me, but he could not guarantee the safety of the car and my family. Because cars in Aden were parked on the street, and we did not have a place as a garage, there was always a risk of vandalism. I told my partner that if possible, I would like to meet with the thief of my car, who was an army sergeant, and he promised to arrange it.

It was noon on one of the days of Ramadan when someone rang the doorbell. Upon opening the door, I was faced with a thin, short, and not very pleasant young man. Seeing my surprised face, he introduced himself, 'I am the one who has your car,' and asked for permission to enter the house. After sitting on a chair, he placed his handgun on the table. I felt that from the beginning, he intended to intimidate. I said to him in Arabic, 'Are you trying to scare me?' He, who seemed to have memorized his lesson well, raised his hands and said, 'No, it is the custom of Arabs that when they enter a house as a guest, they disarm themselves.'

I asked him, 'Are you fasting?' I wanted to offer him a drink, but with mockery of fasting and denial of religion, he introduced himself well and stated that he wanted my car. He said, 'I know that with the help of your partner, you can take the car from me, but know that your partner can take the car back from me, but you will not be able to keep it with you.'

I said, 'I love my car.' He replied, 'I know. I even know how much you bought the car for. I will give you half the price so that you have no further claims and tell your partner that you sold the car to me.' I said, 'What about the Mercedes-Benz repair shop costs?' He indifferently said, 'If they gave you the original car, you should pay them the repair costs.'

I realized I was dealing with a very unreasonable person. Ultimately, with the pleading looks of my dear Mehrangiz, I had no choice but to agree. It was decided to go to the police in two days and conclude the transaction in the presence of the police.

After going to the police, the officer asked, 'Are you satisfied with this transaction?' With strong dissatisfaction, I said, 'I have no choice but to agree.' I handed the car registration card to the police and told him that I was not willing to receive money from such a person. Please take the money from him, count it, and give it to me. And I left the police office with great dissatisfaction.
Interestingly, three months later, my partner Redman informed me that Mr. Sergeant had been executed by his own friends in a revolutionary act.

During this very chaotic and unsafe period, our third child named 'May' was born on the first day of Ridván in Aden. We named her 'May' in memory of the very dear mother, Mrs. Ruhiyyih Khanum, Mrs. May Maxwell. Interestingly, on her birth certificate, where the religion had to be stated, the religion 'Bahá'í' was written with ease during this period. Most of the people in Aden were Sunni, mostly Shafi'i and Hanbali, while the people of Sana'a and northern Yemen were mostly Twelver Shia or Zaidi, who are today known as the Houthis, because the head of their party is known as Houthi.

During this time, Mehrangiz's youngest sister came from India to visit us in Aden, and we managed to obtain a six-month residence visa for her in Aden, which will be continued in the following pages. With the departure of the British from Aden and the terrible wars between the groups claiming future governance, the security situation was extremely chaotic. Previously, Mr. Molavi, who had a green card (permanent residence), had managed to buy a piece of land in the Sheikh Othman area with the intention of building a Hazirat-ul-Quds.

After the formation of the Spiritual Assembly of Aden and with the generous contributions of the friends, the construction of the Hazirat-ul-Quds was completed, and dear Mr. Mahmoud Nejad and his family settled there. One day, his young daughter named Mona was severely hit by a car while crossing the street and was thrown six meters to the other side of the street, but miraculously was not harmed. This incident reminded of another incident for her father, Mr. Mahmoud Nejad, who was saved from a deadly shooting while repairing a radio. This dear father and daughter, who were both later martyred in Shiraz at the beginning of the Islamic Revolution in Iran, seem to have been chosen for martyrdom in the path of the Blessed Beauty, as they were protected from any harm until reaching the rank of martyrdom during the Islamic Revolution.

Of course, the Spiritual Assembly of Aden, when there was relative calm and security, also purchased a piece of land for the construction of a Mashriqu'l-Adhkar, and there were positive thoughts for its construction, but due to the lack of security, this plan did not reach a satisfactory result. And probably the documents related to the Hazirat-ul-Quds and the land of the Mashriqu'l-Adhkar were sent to the Kuwait Assembly.

With the rise of the new government formed by the Communist Party and the numerous economic sanctions that plagued the country, the living conditions of the people became increasingly difficult. This situation caused the Bahá'í migrants residing in Mukalla, the largest city in Hadhramaut, to be unable to renew their residence and come to Aden, considering traveling to other places or northern Yemen. One of these dear migrants, Mr. Mohammad Ali Qadiri, was from the dear friends of Mehrabad, East Azerbaijan, who had come to Mukalla for migration and was engaged in the honorable profession of making iron doors and windows. Also, Mr. Abbas Farhadi and his sister, Hakimeh Khanum, from the very active and selfless friends of Qazvin, and several other friends were expelled due to the non-renewal of their visas. In these unfavorable and unprincipled conditions, I proposed marriage to my sister-in-law, dear Farrokhandeh Khanum Vatankhah, to Mr. Mohammad Ali Qadiri. With their agreement, it came to fruition, and after marriage, since it was not possible to return to Mukalla, their initial place of migration, they migrated to the city of Taiz in northern Yemen and remained there until 2020. They had three children named Keyvan, Ashkan, and Niloufar Khanum. Mr. Qadiri continued working by making aluminum doors and windows. Until in the mentioned year, the friends were forced to leave Yemen. Mr. Keyvan, after graduation, settled in Mukalla as a migrant. Then Ashkan, the younger brother, joined him. After marriage, Ashkan left Mukalla, and Keyvan also left Mukalla after marriage. Mr. Qadiri and his wife stayed in Mukalla for a while to manage their children's shops and then returned to Taiz in northern Yemen. Finally, after a while, and enduring difficult conditions and the imprisonment of their eldest son, Mr. Keyvan, all family members left Yemen and, with divine confirmations, all the family settled in the United States.

During this period, Aden, which was once imagined as a small version of London, due to economic sanctions and severed connections with the Western world, experienced a much worse economic situation. To the extent that the new government created and managed food and vegetable markets, so people had to wait in long lines to buy daily necessities. The first line inside the market was for the payment counter. In this way, the list and quantity of items needed for purchase were given to the cashier, and their price was paid. The second line was for collecting the list of purchased items like potatoes, onions, carrots, etc. The lines and purchases led to problems because some necessary items were not supplied on time, and the paid amount was non-refundable. The government fruit and vegetable market was located in the parking lot of a building near our shop, whose owner was a friend of ours. Since there was a need to procure food at least three times a week, a plan was devised for one of our daughters to sleep at our friend's house, located above the parking lot, the night before the purchase, and be the first in line at 6 AM. The market opened at 7 AM.

Before 7 o'clock, we would be present in the queue for shopping, and our child would come home to have breakfast and get ready to go to school. One of us would stand in the payment line, and the other would check the available goods in the store, creating a shopping list based on that. With the payment made at the counter, the daily shopping would be completed. This planning saved time and prevented the accumulation of unnecessary items. After completing the shopping, I would go home and take the children, who were ready to go to school in the Tawahi area, and then return to the shop to start working.

In the building where we lived, there were ten apartment units, and I didn't know most of the residents, but Mehrangiz Khanum had connections with all the women. During this time, Mehrangiz Jan served as a kind grandmother to all the women living in our building. Whenever any of the women had a child, Mehrangiz Jan supported them, and they were very pleased with this kindness. Additionally, Mehrangiz Khanum taught English to their older children and treated them like her own children.

A few months after we settled in this building, a young couple moved in on the fourth floor. The young lady had a special interest in Mehrangiz Jan from the very beginning, and dear Mehrangiz also showed special attention to her, especially because she was a newlywed and had moved away from her family. After some time, this lady became pregnant and gave birth to a baby girl. Mehrangiz Jan would often take care of the mother and her baby in the mornings, bathing and cleaning the little girl and reciting prayers for her.

The little girl, who had become very sweet-tongued and lovable, was a year and a half old when her mother told Mehrangiz Khanum that her daughter was reciting a poem whose meaning they did not understand. Mehrangiz Jan asked the little girl to recite the poem for her, and the sweet child, with her childish voice, recited the prayer 'O God, grant a pure heart like a pearl.' Mehrangiz Khanum explained to the girl's mother that she had been reciting this prayer for her every day to put her to sleep and translated the meaning of the prayer, which was in Persian, for her.

One day, the mother of this little girl said to Mehrangiz Jan, 'Um Mitra' (meaning Mitra's mother) and continued that she needed to share a truth with her. 'My husband is one of the heads of the intelligence department of the new government, and our residence in this building is not a coincidence. We moved here to investigate your family life, and all your actions and behaviors have been under our observation. But now we are assured of your purity and service, and we recognize you as our best friends. Please inform us of any service we can provide, and we will be diligent in doing so.'

The security situation became so dire that one day my partner, Radman, came to the shop and expressed that he felt very threatened and needed to leave Aden as soon as possible and go to Sana'a, the capital of North Yemen. He asked me to cover the living expenses of his elderly parents. Also, for a while at the beginning of the opening of the eyeglass shop, my partner, Mr. Radman, asked me to pay him a monthly amount. When I asked him why he needed this small amount despite the high income from the casino, he honestly said that he wanted to cover the education expenses of his children studying in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, from the lawful income of the eyeglass shop.

Radman went to Sana'a, and soon all his properties, casino, and shop were confiscated by the new government. Meanwhile, our stay in Aden came to an end and was not renewed. I would go to sleep at night with worry until one night I had a strange dream. In the dream, all the household items were loaded onto a truck, and my family and I were sitting on it while I was holding the truck's steering wheel, crossing a steep mountain slope when suddenly the truck's steering went out of my control. In that state, I suggested to Mehrangiz Jan that she and the children get off the truck, but she opposed this suggestion and stayed with me. Ultimately, the truck was speeding down the mountain, but at the bottom of the mountain, a large white sheet was spread out, and Abdu'l-Bahá was standing at the end of it. The truck gently stopped on the white sheet.
After having this true dream, we realized that there would be difficulties ahead, but the end would be bright and hopeful.

One afternoon, an officer who had a cloth tied around his waist came to the shop and said he was sent by the Minister of Finance to seal the shop and asked me to lock it and accompany him. After leaving the shop and locking the door, the officer took me to the police station located on top of a hill and handed me over to the duty officer as a suspect on behalf of the Minister of Finance. Inside the police station, there were several detainees. It was my first time entering a police station, and I was restless. I approached the duty officer and asked if he knew me. He pleasantly acknowledged knowing me, although I did not recognize him. I stayed at the police station until late at night and talked to the duty officer about my situation. Eventually, the duty officer allowed me to go home on the condition that I return to the police station at 4:30 in the morning so that he, whose shift ended at five in the morning, could hand me over to the new duty officer along with the other detainees. I thanked him.

I went home and recounted the story to Mehrangiz Jan. Our first decision was to form the Spiritual Assembly of Aden and consult about the problem that had arisen. From 9 PM to 11 PM, we spent time in consultation and prayer. Consequently, the two of us decided that dear Mehrangiz would bake a delicious cake, and early in the morning, with the taxi that would take me to the police station, Mehrangiz Jan and Mitra would be dropped off at the Minister of Finance's house, which was on our way, so that Mehrangiz Jan could explain the situation to the minister's wife and ask for her help.

At 4:30 in the morning, I returned to the police station. At 8 in the morning, the officer who had arrested me entered the police station. Mehrangiz Jan also arrived at the police station with a rented car and, after ensuring that I got into the car with the government officer and went to the Finance Department, she returned home.

The officer took me to the Finance Department to see the Minister of Finance. After greeting, I asked the minister about the reason for sealing the shop and handing me over to the police. The minister explained that they had received a report claiming that I had taken my partner Mr. Radman's share out of the country, and this act was considered a major crime under the current circumstances. Therefore, for further investigation, they sealed the shop and arrested me.

I told the minister that I was ready for any investigation, but for your information, I have not taken any money out of the country. Mr. Radman has elderly parents and many sisters and brothers, all residing in Aden. You can send an officer to them and ask how their living expenses have been covered since their son, Mr. Radman, left Aden. The minister hesitantly asked what I would do if Mr. Radman's parents denied this. I replied that as a Bahá'í, I have always been truthful and will not lie, as it goes against my religious beliefs. The minister sophistically asked, 'Do you mean Muslims are liars?' I said, 'God forbid. I did not say Muslims lie. I said that because I am a Bahá'í, I have only spoken and will only speak the truth.' After some discussion, he finally agreed to conduct the investigation and allowed me to return home until then.

When I returned home, I recounted the meeting with the minister to Mehrangiz Jan and asked her to explain how she entered the minister's house. Mehrangiz Khanum explained, 'After getting out of the car, I waited for a while so as not to disturb the minister's wife early in the morning. Finally, at 7 AM, I rang the doorbell, and the minister's wife personally opened the door. She listened to my words with kindness and empathy, accepted the cake I had brought, and later provided the utmost cooperation.'

The minister's wife, noting that their house had two doors and her husband did not wish to meet visitors at home, arranged for Mehrangiz Jan to wait in the hallway until the minister left his room so she could speak with him. As soon as the minister came out of his room, my wife explained the situation to him in English, and the minister promised to assist in resolving the issue of sealing the shop favorably.

After spending nights filled with anxiety and severe insomnia, one night at 1:30 AM, as I was restless and Mehrangiz Khanum was sleeping peacefully, I woke her up and asked, 'With this storm raging in our lives, how can you rest so calmly?' She asked me, 'Are you anxious?' I said, 'Keep in mind that our material life is disintegrating (as I had previously told her about the journey from Mashhad to Dubai with the little capital my mother had given me). She fully remembered and reminded me that acquiring material wealth comes from health and perseverance. Now, even if we lose our wealth, meaning it is confiscated, I am confident in your health and perseverance. She reminded me that we are now a family with three children, full of love and cooperation, and I fully support the family with all my strength. The essence of her words was that we gained wealth through work and effort, and now we are losing it. What is important is the health and hope that we all must have. With calm and encouraging words, she reassured me. She told me that relying on trust in God and family support, any problem can be overcome. These words gave me hope, and I was able to end the night with more peace.

The next morning, I went to the tax office, and the minister told me that investigations had shown that I had paid for Mr. Radman's parents' living expenses. However, due to my partner leaving the country and half of the shop's capital belonging to him, the government decided to seize his share and become my partner instead of Radman. I was not interested in partnering with the government.

Considering that my stay in Aden had ended and the immigration office was unresponsive, Mehrangiz shared the issue with a lady whose husband was an intelligence officer and whose brother was the secretary of the interior minister. With her help, a meeting with the interior minister was arranged. After hearing my problem, the interior minister decided to grant me a temporary six-month permit but emphasized that the extension of my stay must be done legally.

Subsequently, the finance minister decided to form a committee of three people to evaluate the shop's capital. After 20 days, the value of the capital was determined, and my share was set at one million dollars. However, given the complex conditions in the country and my reluctance to partner with the communist government, I decided to avoid this partnership. The finance minister stated that if I did not cooperate with the government, my share would be confiscated. Ultimately, he suggested that to leave the country, I should train a Yemeni person in eyeglass making so that he could run the shop as I did.

I had a very friendly relationship with the owner of an eyeglass shop in the Crater area. His apprentice, Mr. Suleiman, was a very understanding and wise person. When I told him about the finance minister and the blocking of my share in the shop, he expressed deep regret and said he would do whatever he could to help. I told him that if we had sessions every day for a month, I could teach him all the tasks of lens grinding and practice together to ensure he could handle the work. He, affected by the inhumane decision of the finance minister, reluctantly accepted this proposal. From the next day, he prepared a notebook and pen, and I taught him for two hours a day. Since he already knew eyeglass making and was familiar with most terms, he only had issues with grinding prescription lenses. By drawing various diagrams and teaching formulas, and with his intense interest in learning, after a month, he stated that he could perform the tasks well. I told him we should go to the minister, and he should declare that he had learned all the assignments and was ready to run the shop. Mr. Suleiman was worried he might make mistakes in practice and cause damage, hesitating. I assured him that since half of the capital belonged to me, he should not worry.
After a month, we went to the minister, and Mr. Suleiman declared that he had learned the assignments well. The minister then handed over our passports, and we said our goodbyes.

During this time, to avoid being idle, I went to the Chinese hospital in Yemen and asked the eye doctor, who was aware of the closure of our eyeglass shop, to introduce me to an acupuncture specialist. The eye doctor kindly introduced me, and I spent some time learning and working in the acupuncture department of the hospital.

When leaving Aden, the acupuncture doctor gifted me a statue showing 450 important points for needle insertion in the body, along with some needles and a book on acupuncture. Unfortunately, during the trip to Iran and in Abadan, the suitcase containing these gifts was stolen, and only the book remained.

Since the shop was closed and my time was spent teaching Mr. Suleiman and going to the Chinese hospital, I had the opportunity in the mornings to go with Mr. Molavi's service car. One morning, I noticed a police van parked in front of Mr. Molavi's shop, and they had put him in the police car. I inquired about the reason for the arrest, and the police said they had orders to arrest people without residence permits and send them to the northern Yemeni border within twelve hours. I requested the police officer that if any Adeni citizens could guarantee Mr. Molavi's stay for a while so he could arrange his shop and life affairs and leave Aden. The police officer, who was kind and knew Mr. Molavi had permanent residence from the British era in Aden, and understood Mr. Molavi's chaotic situation, agreed with me.

With the help, guarantee, and support of Mr. Tawfiq Saqqaf, who was a Yemeni Bahá'í residing in Aden, we were able to obtain a temporary residence permit for Mr. Mowlavi so that he could organize his affairs and leave Aden with his family. Ultimately, a ticket was purchased for Mr. Mowlavi to leave for Sana'a in North Yemen. I also decided to get my exit ticket one day earlier than Mr. Mowlavi's family so that they, who were the first migrants to Aden, would also be the last to be expelled. It is worth mentioning that a few days before this incident, I had a dream. We were sitting with Mr. Mowlavi, his wife, and Mehrangiz Jan on a small hill surrounded by a sea of water. We were all worried about how to save ourselves from that hill and return to our homes. We couldn't find a way to escape until I noticed a deep well in the middle of the hill. We were contemplating passing through the well to escape the current situation when Mr. Mowlavi shocked us all by jumping into the well. Upon closer inspection of the well's opening, I noticed steps had been installed inside. The three of us remaining went down the steps to join Mr. Mowlavi. At the bottom of the well, there was a beautiful lush garden. I woke up from the dream with the feeling that although problems would arise for Mr. Mowlavi, the outcome would be satisfactory, and I shared my dream with his wife.

Before going to the airport, the wife of our friend gave Mehrangiz Jan her husband's very confidential phone number so that if any problems arose at the airport, we could inform him and he would assist in resolving the issue. At Aden airport, we boarded the plane without any obstacles and saw her husband at the foot of the airplane stairs, who had come to bid farewell. This kindness compensated for all the past fatigue.

We flew from Aden to Taiz and settled at Mr. Qadiri's house, who was a migrant there. Messrs. Radman and Ibrahim Laghman, who had also left Aden, were working in a company that Mr. Radman had established in Taiz. Mr. Radman asked me to stay and manage a shop we had in Hodeida. I told Mr. Radman that I wanted to hand over the Hodeida shop to Mr. Saleki, one of the Yemeni migrants who was running the shop in Hodeida, and go to Iran with my family for a while.

Mr. Radman agreed with my proposal, and we decided to sell the Hodeida shop to Mr. Saleki. I also took care of the shop's affairs, settled the accounts, determined each partner's share, and obtained flight tickets through Sana'a and Kuwait to enter Abadan, Iran. Thus, the migration journey that began in 1955 ended in 1975 after 20 years.

After arriving in Abadan, we took a taxi to Ahvaz and reached my sister-in-law's house, who was an employee of the oil company, at 4 AM. After a short rest, I realized that a handbag was missing from our belongings. Since I had the taxi number that brought us from Abadan to Ahvaz, I went to Abadan airport and found the taxi in question. I asked the driver to return the left-behind handbag, but he strongly denied having it. Inside that handbag were gifts for relatives, a statue, and acupuncture needles that a Chinese doctor had given me.

This was my first negative and unreasonable experience after returning to Iran after twenty years. I asked the driver to take all the valuables from the bag and just return my optometry certificate to me. But he, who had denied it from the start, was not willing to fulfill this request. I threatened to file a complaint against him. He, being a sergeant in the army, threatened, 'I will find your address in Ahvaz and make you regret this complaint.' After consulting with Mehrangiz Jan, we decided to forgo retrieving this suitcase.

Fortunately, a house had already been built in the Kianpars area of Ahvaz by Mr. Adelati, my sister-in-law's husband (my brother-in-law), and after a few days, we moved there. Kianpars was one of the affluent and newly established areas of Ahvaz. From the beginning of our arrival in Ahvaz, I tried to set up an optometry shop and start working. However, after visiting the health department, I realized that to establish a shop, I had to participate in an exam held every few years for the experimental optometry profession, obtain a diploma, and go through legal procedures to be granted permission to open a shop.

Opposite our house lived Dr. Jazayeri, one of the well-known ophthalmologists in Ahvaz. His wife became very close to Mehrangiz Khanum, and since they had two daughters the same age as our children and their house had a pool, they wanted our children to play with theirs in the pool. Dr. Jazayeri also showed great kindness and even gave me a written promise of assistance for establishing the optometry shop.

Since it was necessary to wait for some time to establish the optician's shop, I started working as a cashier at Firooz Company and simultaneously continued my night studies to complete my diploma, which I had left unfinished at the beginning of our migration. During that time, some of Dr. Jazayeri's relatives in Ahvaz were Bahá'í and some were Muslim, including the Friday prayer leader of Ahvaz, who was a close relative of his.

Next to our house in Kianpars was the house of Mr. Nafisi, one of the Bahá'ís from Yazd. It was rented by employees of an Iranian-Japanese company. The son-in-law of the company's president, a young Iranian who had recently married, lived there with his wife. Since the bride's parents lived in Tehran, my wife, Mehrangiz, soon took on the role of the neighbor's mother. This affection became so deep that during childbirth, Mehrangiz stayed with the woman in the hospital until morning.

A few days after the baby's birth, the girl's parents came to Ahvaz to see their first grandchild and learned about Mehrangiz's maternal companionship. The girl's father expressed a desire to meet with me. He was Dr. Jenidi, a university professor, very astute and perceptive in understanding issues. After a few minutes of conversation, he asked, 'Where do you work?' I said, 'For now, until I can start my main work, which is opticianry, I am working at Firooz Company.' He asked, 'Are you a Bahá'í?' Upon my affirmative answer, he stated, 'Your wife's actions and her selfless maternal behavior can only be attributed to a Bahá'í. I have many Bahá'í friends in Tehran. They are very trustworthy and honest people.' In short, he offered me a job as a cashier at an Iranian-Japanese company called Paisaz, with a salary three times higher than Firooz Company and with insurance benefits. 51% of the company's shares belonged to him and 49% to the Japanese. I mentioned that I needed to leave the company an hour early in the evenings for two years to attend night classes to get my diploma, which was accepted without objection. This company had 500 workers and 35 employees.

In 1977, the opticianry exam was held, and I participated from Ahvaz. However, for unknown reasons, I was not awarded the opticianry diploma. One night, Dr. Jazayeri came to our door and informed us that he had been warned by Islamic propaganda not to associate with his Bahá'í neighbor. As 1978 approached and strikes began, I managed to obtain my diploma and even participated in the national university entrance exam. After the revolution's victory and the start of the Iran-Iraq war, we stayed in Ahvaz until Iraqi soldiers reached the city. Due to the intensity of the conflict and daily Iraqi attacks, we had to flee Ahvaz to settle in Shiraz.

After settling in Shiraz, in partnership with one of the Bahá'ís named Mr. Tashakkori, who had also returned from Abu Dhabi and settled in Shiraz, we bought the ownership of a shop and opened a supermarket. A few months after starting the supermarket, a friend from Ahvaz informed me that my name had been announced on Ahvaz radio, stating that I must present myself to the Revolutionary Court. Since Bahá'ís across Iran were being imprisoned and their properties confiscated, especially in Shiraz where it led to martyrdom, I refrained from going to Ahvaz. During this period, our first daughter, Mitra, married Mr. Amir Fallah, one of the Bahá'ís from Rafsanjan.

After hearing the news from Ahvaz and Mehrangiz's insistence on following up on the reason for my summons, Mehrangiz decided to go to Ahvaz in my place to inquire about the reason for my summons. During this period, our second daughter, Fariba, got engaged to Mr. Iraj Khalili, a young man from Mashhad, in Shiraz. After consulting and considering the concerns, Mehrangiz went to Ahvaz and visited the prosecutor's office. However, she was detained there and imprisoned for five and a half months.

Fariba's wedding took place in Mashhad during her mother's imprisonment. I went through a very difficult time because Mitra was about to give birth, Fariba had to get married, and our third child was expelled from school for being Bahá'í. During this time, our first grandchild, Shamis, was born. I decided to somehow convey this news to Mehrangiz. I sent a telegram from Kerman to Ahvaz prison, 'To Mehrangiz Vatan Khah, with great joy, we congratulate you on the birth of your first dear grandchild. We are all well. Fariba has moved to her new home. Wishing you health, Prakash.' After Mehrangiz's imprisonment, I considered selling and closing the supermarket and relocating from Shiraz to Mashhad. With the sale of the supermarket, our period of homelessness and wandering began. Later, Mehrangiz said, 'In prison, I was not subjected to any harassment, but the lack of news about the family's situation caused severe illness, so much so that during the five and a half months of imprisonment, I lost twelve kilograms. But with the arrival of the telegram, a comfort was achieved that surprised all the prisoners. Most importantly, everyone thought the telegram was sent by one of her Indian friends.'

After five and a half months, by posting my brother Mahmoud Agha Kholousi's house as bail, I managed to bring Mehrangiz, in a semi-conscious state, from Ahvaz to Shiraz by car and, with rapid treatment, transferred her to Mashhad by plane two days later. We spent some time in Mashhad on necessary treatments and her recovery. Eager to see their mother, Mitra and dear Shamis flew from Rafsanjan to Mashhad. At the airport, Mehrangiz's meeting with her first grandchild was a very memorable and unique moment.

During one of our trips to Rafsanjan to visit Mitra and the family, we spent a night at the home of Mr. Mohammad Fallah, Shamiss's grandfather. Shamiss was almost a year old and very sweet-tongued. I wanted to know if she recognized family members. While she was resting in her mother's arms, I asked her, 'Who is that gentleman?' pointing to Mr. Fallah. She easily replied, 'Father dear.' She referred to her mother as 'Mama,' and when I pointed to myself, she said, 'Baba Zia.' When I pointed to Mehrangiz, whom she had seen just a few days before, she struggled to say 'Mama Mehrangiz,' but the pronunciation was difficult for her. After a brief pause, she said, 'Mama Zia.' We laughed a lot and said goodnight, leaving the gathering to sleep. The next morning, dear Mehrangiz asked me, 'What was the name of 'Abdu'l-Bahá's daughter?' I said, 'Miss Ziaieh.' With complete sincerity and affection, she said, 'The dream I had at the beginning of our migration to Yemen, which I told you about, has come true today through the words of this child. 'Abdu'l-Bahá has accepted me as his daughter.' I realized that I would no longer be able to oppose her wishes, which were always right and justified. From that day until now, as I write these memories forty-two years later, no one has called her by her name, and everyone knows her as Mama Zia.

In Mashhad, with the money from selling the Shiraz grocery items, we bought a house in the Sheshsad Dastgah area and settled there. Many people came to Mehrangiz for English language lessons, and since she set the teaching fee according to the students' abilities, their number increased daily.

One day, one of the students said that their Quran teacher, known as Shariati, was interested in learning English and mentioned that they thought he intended to guide Mehrangiz because he knew she was a Bahá'í. Mehrangiz always taught at home and refused to go to the students' homes, believing that the time spent traveling could be better used teaching another student.

When the Quran teacher's appointment coincided with my presence at home, Mrs. Shariati entered, and after introducing herself, I asked if her father had a notary office at Sarab Square in Mashhad. She said, 'Yes, my father was the head of that office.' I said, 'Your father was the only notary in Mashhad who drafted marriage declarations for Bahá'ís. My wife and I had our marriage declaration drafted in his office.' When she realized her father had cooperated with the Bahá'ís of Mashhad, she was very pleased and asked my dear Mehrangiz to help her write a letter in English to her daughter-in-law in Germany.

The affection between her and Mehrangiz grew so deep that the following week, she invited us to lunch at her garden in Shandiz, Mashhad, and maintained this relationship for many years. The story of our marriage declaration registration at Mr. Shariati's notary office, which I recounted to their daughter, was that at the time, the Pahlavi government did not recognize Bahá'ís as an official religion. As a result, in provincial centers, a notary whose owner was ethically more lenient and less prejudiced was designated for Bahá'í personal affairs. Her father provided us with this assistance. The story was that after twelve years of marriage, we came to Mashhad. We arranged to draft our marriage certificate at his official office. It is customary for the exact content of the declaration, which is given to the applicant as a document, to be recorded in the official notary office and signed by the applicant. Mehrangiz said, 'Mr. Shariati, I don't have a Persian signature. Is it okay if I sign your office in English?' Mr. Shariati replied, 'An English signature is forbidden in our office. We must write that due to the illiteracy of the bride, a fingerprint is certified.' Mehrangiz asked what 'bride' meant. I said it means spouse, meaning you. She stood up and politely said, 'Mr. Shariati, does literacy mean writing in Persian? I speak six languages, but I can't write in Persian. If you leave Iran, what other language do you know?' Mr. Shariati, realizing he was at a loss, said, 'What do you suggest I write?' Mehrangiz said, 'You should write that due to not knowing how to write in Persian, a fingerprint is taken.' And thus, our declaration was registered.

In the early years of the revolution, due to the prohibition of work for the Bahá'ís by government agencies, most of them turned to menial jobs like driving, trucking, selling vegetables, and similar occupations. Like many friends in Mashhad, I bought a van and engaged in transporting goods, selling fire extinguishers, distributing machine-made bread, and even transporting melons and watermelons.

For the second time, I took the optician exam in Mashhad, but again the result was negative. This meant that I had passed the exam, but the result was deliberately given to someone else. Finally, in 1988, they announced that the last series of exams for experienced opticians would be held in Iran. In Tehran, since no one knew my surname, I was able to register and, with perseverance and determination, succeeded in obtaining a diploma in practical opticianry.

However, this diploma had a major problem: it specified Tehran as the place of business, while I intended to open a shop in Mashhad. This issue created a significant obstacle in my work. With much effort, this problem, like other issues, was resolved, and the place of business was changed from Tehran to Mashhad.

In Sajjad Boulevard, Mashhad, I established an optical shop in partnership with one of the Bahá'í friends. Before opening the shop, I applied for membership in the Mashhad Opticians' Union. One of the conditions for obtaining a business permit was membership in the respective unions of each trade. However, the union's response was delayed, so I prepared and opened the shop on a leasehold and rental basis. It didn't take long for my business to be welcomed and flourish.

A few months after establishing the shop, I faced an illegal warning from the union. They claimed that I had opened an optical shop without permission. After extensive correspondence with the union and no resolution, the threat to seal the shop continued. In response, I stated that I had adhered to all legal regulations for opening an optical shop and that if they proceeded to seal the shop, I would retaliate by declaring that the shop was sealed due to the religious minority status of its owner, so that people would know the reason for sealing the shop was solely religious prejudice and opposition to Bahá'ís.

Every year, I renewed my membership application with the union, but received no response. Nevertheless, my business continued to thrive day by day. During that period of unemployment and hardship, I was practically managing the livelihood of four families. One of the benefits of union membership was that some frames and lenses were provided to union members at a lower price. Additionally, government organizations would contract optical purchases with more consideration for union members.

With the opening of the shop, most of the needs of the union members were supplied by my shop. The reason for this success was my good credit and prompt payment of invoices to the merchants in Tehran. In Aden, there was no credit or post-dated checks, and I implemented the same method in Mashhad. This approach was so well-received by the optical merchants in Tehran that one day a driver arrived at the shop with a van containing several cartons of sunglasses and handed me invoices. Since such an order had not been placed by my shop, I immediately contacted the merchant who sent the shipment, thanked him, and expressed my inability to pay for the goods sent.

The response from the respected Tehran merchant was so encouraging and hopeful that I realized that by relying on Bahá'í teachings, we could manage our material affairs in the difficult conditions of the Islamic Revolution. He stated that he did not know me, nor did I know them in Tehran. Over the past three years, I have imported a significant amount of sunglasses from China into Iran and have sales representatives in various provinces of Iran. In Khorasan province, after much searching, colleagues provided us with your shop's address and introduced you as an example of honesty and good credit. He further stated that the goods sent to Mashhad are on consignment to you and you should not pay for them at present. After selling, you will have a fifteen percent commission. Send us the checks received from merchants. Please ensure that you sell the goods to individuals whose checks do not bounce.

Since the quantity of goods received was very large, I requested several optical sales representatives to show the sunglasses to optical sellers in Mashhad, take orders, and after delivering the goods, hand over the received checks with a payment period of less than two months. To encourage more activity from the sales representatives, I set their commission, which was 5% of sales in Mashhad, to 7%. This move was very well-received and resulted in very high sales that continued for years.

One day, I received a letter from the union inviting me to a union meeting. I went to the meeting with a friend. The union president stated that if we have not stopped your business until now, it is due to the respect the union members have for you and your manner of dealing with people and merchants. However, we have decided in the Opticians' Union that we will not have a Bahá'í optician in Mashhad and Qom, two religious cities in Iran. We will assist you in every way possible if you kindly relocate to Tehran, Isfahan, or Shiraz, and if you do not cooperate, your shop will be sealed. Since I did not expect to hear such words from the union president, I angrily said, 'Bahá'í youths who go to the war front as soldiers are Iranian citizens and must go, and their fathers, who are responsible for providing for their families, are deprived of such a right.' A bearded young man sitting among the union members gestured for me to leave the meeting with him. He then said, 'I ask you not to react to the words of the union members.' I asked, 'What is your position in this meeting?' He said, 'I am the representative of the Ministry of Commerce in the Opticians' Union. The union cannot close your shop. This is the right of the Ministry of Commerce. They are bluffing.' Hearing this, I felt relieved. We returned to the meeting and left without any conclusion.

One of the problems I faced every year was the issue of paying business taxes. The tax office calculated whatever it wanted for our shop. Every year, I had to pay the calculated tax amount by writing a protest letter. Until a few years after the shop was established, I received an invitation from the tax office to attend a meeting to provide explanations. I entered the meeting at the Mashhad tax office with the same friend I had previously gone to the Opticians' Union with. After introducing the members of the meeting, I realized that three of them were expert assessors of the tax office. After greeting and introducing myself, one of the assessors said, 'We have investigated and realized that you have been wronged.' Not expecting to hear such words after years of writing letters to the tax office, I involuntarily said, 'Glory to the Creator. Please explain how this matter was revealed to you?' All three laughed loudly, and one of them said, 'The tax office's method since the beginning of the revolution was that since people's financial situation was chaotic and disorganized, and few tradesmen had a proper account book, every year the unions of each trade were responsible for determining the amount of tax quota for their members. That is, the tax office would determine an estimated tax amount for each shop, considering the location, sales, and establishment history of the shop and the type of customers they had, and send it to the respective union for final review and consultation. The union, with expert opinions and relationships with its members, would adjust the tax amount determined by the tax office for each shop and sometimes request a discount of up to fifty percent. After reviewing all aspects, we realized that there are 602 optical shops in Mashhad, and the best and top-rated of these optical shops paid sixty thousand tomans in taxes this year. But this year, you paid four hundred and twenty thousand tomans in taxes. Considering that your shop is rated as second-class by the tax office, our question to you is, 'How and why did you pay such a high tax? Did you have such an income that you paid it?' I said, 'Please request our shop's tax file from the archive so I can respond.' The file was placed on the table. I said, 'Every year when I received the tax payment form, I wrote a protest letter, copies of which are now in the file, and since no response was given by the tax office, I was forced to pay the tax amount requested by the tax office and explained that since I am a member of the Bahá'í minority community, and until now, despite repeated requests, the union has not accepted me as a member, and I did not think it wise to add a problem to my problems by not paying taxes, so I paid the amounts requested by the tax office.'

After my explanations, one of the assessors said it would be better to secure your membership in the Opticians' Union, as this issue has led to your protest letters being ignored and your taxes doubling. However, this year we will refund 120,000 tomans of your paid checks, and for the next three years, you will not have additional taxes. They canceled the checks made payable to the Tax Office and returned them. Additionally, they stated, 'From this year, we have increased the taxes of all opticians in Mashhad by 100%.' I expressed my discontent, saying, 'It is not fair to punish 601 other members because of one person.' They replied, 'When you can pay the amount declared by the Tax Office, the other members will also be able to pay.' We took the 120,000 tomans of canceled tax checks and left the meeting. I told my companion, 'I want to meet the head of the union and discuss the matter with him.' He disagreed, saying, 'They will only become more stubborn and hostile,' but I intended to inform the head of the union, who was a reasonable and almost impartial person, about the refund of 120,000 tomans from the Tax Office, which had never happened in the history of the tax administration, and the reason for the 100% tax increase for union members.

I immediately went to the head of the Opticians' Union and explained the situation, especially showing him the refunded tax checks, which was unprecedented, and explained the reason for the 100% tax increase for the opticians. I also pointed out that out of 602 optician shops in Mashhad, only one is owned by a Bahá'í. This reflects the extreme narrow-mindedness and lack of regard for fellow humans by the Opticians' Union. I mentioned that during the tax meeting, I expressed my dissatisfaction with the increase in taxes for other opticians. He paid close attention to my words and stated that one of the union members, who recites the Quran in leadership meetings, was the cause of these problems for me and other opticians. He said, 'Every year, the issue of your shop was raised in the union, and our Quran-reciting friend opposed getting a tax reduction for your shop. Since all members were afraid of him, we took no action, resulting in your taxes exceeding the balance over several years, arousing the curiosity of tax assessors, exempting you from additional taxes for three years, and raising the taxes for other opticians by 100%, and refunding your excess taxes.' He was very upset and apologized, especially requesting that you apply for union membership this year.

According to the head of the union's request, I applied for membership, but after a month or two, they replied that membership in the union is not possible under your name and surname. If you wish to have your shop as a member, it must be registered under someone else's name. I inquired about the reason. They said since most of the Kholousi family have prison records, the Opticians' Union does not wish to have such members. Most of my brothers were imprisoned for some time after the revolution due to their association with the Bahá'í Faith. To avoid prolonging the membership process, I requested membership in the union under my partner's name. After the fingerprinting ceremony and initial approvals, my partner left for the United States to visit his family. A few days after my partner's trip to America, I received a letter in his name stating that the membership application had been approved and that I must attend a one-month class on customer interaction to approve your membership and issue a work permit. I was back to square one. I consulted a friend to solve the problem. He said he was acquainted with the person responsible for the above class. By visiting the training class supervisor and explaining that my friend was traveling to America, he said if you are willing to participate, I have no objection. I attended the aforementioned class for a month, and he marked the attendance sheet and sent it to the union. After a while, an official work permit and ten-year membership in the union were issued in my partner's name, while a five-year work permit was issued for other union members. This was another one of the divine confirmations.

One of the problems Bahá'ís faced in the Islamic Republic of Iran from the establishment of the Islamic Republic was the prohibition of issuing passports and traveling abroad. Finally, after 22 years, we managed to obtain a passport. During the prohibition of passport issuance, my mother-in-law became seriously ill in India, and despite repeated visits, we were unable to obtain a passport to travel and see her. Ultimately, the dear mother passed away while waiting to meet her loved ones.

After receiving the first passport from the Islamic Republic, we purchased a ticket to travel to India via Dubai. After a 15-day stay in Dubai and meeting with loved ones we knew from the past and present in that city, we even took a short trip to Khor Fakkan and introduced my wife to the cities and places where I lived before marriage. We greatly enjoyed meeting the esteemed migrants in the Dubai and Sharjah area.

We spent some time traveling in India and visiting friends and family, and spent a few days in Delhi to visit the Mashriqu'l-Adhkár. Then we returned to Iran. Since there was a risk of the passport not being renewed, we took a trip to Ashgabat, Turkmenistan, which is about four hours by car from Mashhad, with my wife, accompanied by Mrs. Nahid Tavakoli and Mrs. Ladan Foroughian, and spent a very pleasant week.

Before the trip, I obtained the phone number of a friend from Mashhad who had a distant relative in Ashgabat, hoping that with his help, we could visit the site of the first Bahá'í Mashriqu'l-Adhkár built during the time of ‘Abdu’l-Bahá. Although we went to Ashgabat with a seven-day tour, our accommodation was arranged at the Oil Company Hotel in Ashgabat. After the usual sightseeing, I was determined to find the Bahá'ís of Ashgabat with the help of the phone number I had and fulfill my wish.

After much delay and not getting results from repeated calls to the phone number I had, I asked our tour leader about the reason. He said that in the area you are calling, new cabling is being done, and the phones will be connected in an hour. I called the mentioned number again, and an elderly lady who spoke Persian with difficulty answered. I realized that she was a very esteemed doctor. I had heard that Mrs. Shamsi Khanum Sadaqat, whom I knew and who had migrated to Cyprus from Mashhad 70 years ago, had returned to Ashgabat from America. I asked the lady who answered the phone if I could visit Mrs. Shamsi Khanum Sadaqat. She asked, 'Where are you from, and how do you know Mrs. Sadaqat?' I replied, 'I am Kholousi, I have come from Mashhad, and I am the brother of the person who bought your father's house when you migrated to Cyprus.' I gave her my address. She promised to convey my message to Mrs. Sadaqat.

At eight o'clock in the evening, Mrs. Shamsi Sadaqat, along with twelve other Bahá'ís from Ashgabat, came to the hotel. The meeting of Iranian Bahá'ís with the Bahá'ís of Ashgabat after many years was truly remarkable and indescribable. They were very kind. We mentioned that we were very eager to visit the Mashriqu'l-Adhkár of Ashgabat. It was decided that at 5 AM, one of the Tajik Bahá'ís would take us by car to the site of the Mashriqu'l-Adhkár, where some Bahá'ís from Ashgabat would also be present.

The next morning, four of us arrived at the site of the Mashriqu'l-Adhkár. It was a very beautiful space, and a statue of the famous Turkmen poet, Makhtumquli, was respectfully installed there. Makhtumquli has eloquent poems in Turkmen about the new revelation and the open horizons of the future. Friends explained that the original building of the Mashriqu'l-Adhkár was destroyed in 1948 due to a severe earthquake in Ashgabat, and later, with the approval of the then Soviet government, it was completely demolished to avoid the risk of collapse. Currently, the land is under the possession of the Spiritual Assembly of Ashgabat. We inquired about the condition of the Bahá'ís. They said that according to the current laws, we can hold administrative meetings, but a government official must be present at the meeting. Interestingly, one of the government officials who attends these meetings has developed a strong inclination towards the Bahá'í Faith along with his family. On the grounds of the Mashriqu'l-Adhkár, near the statue of Makhtumquli, benches were arranged, and Mrs. Shamsi Sadaqat explained that after the collapse of the Soviet government and the so-called Iron Curtain being lifted, and the opening of travel to Russia, Mrs. Ruhiyyih Khanum and Mr. Furutan, Hands of the Cause of God, sat on these benches during their first trip to Ashgabat and prayed. We also offered prayers and thanksgiving. Accompanied by the Bahá'ís, we headed to the home of a young Kazakh Bahá'í couple who had recently married and apparently the bride was in the state of search for truth, located on the fifth floor of a tower in the middle of Ashgabat, for breakfast. We were met with a royal breakfast table that we did not expect. Breakfast lasted two to three hours. Most of the Bahá'ís present at the meeting knew Persian. Since it was the day of our return to Mashhad, we said goodbye to the gathering and were accompanied by the homeowner in a very large and elegant elevator. In the elevator, I noticed that the bride, the homeowner, was holding and kissing dear Mama Zia intensely. After getting off the elevator, the bride asked her husband, who was supposed to take us to our destination, to wait a few minutes so she could return home and complete a task. After the elevator returned, the bride came back with a precious blanket as a gift for dear Mehrangiz. Since we had to leave for Mashhad that day, there was no opportunity to talk about the hugging incident in the elevator. After traveling a bit, I inquired about the situation. Dear Mehrangiz said, "I didn't know that after reciting the prayers, we would go directly from the grounds of the Mashriqu'l-Adhkár for breakfast. So after entering the homeowner's house and especially realizing that it had only been a few days since their wedding, we were all deeply saddened and upset to be met with such a royal reception without any gift. In the elevator, I suddenly took off my gold ring with the Greatest Name and placed it on the bride's finger as she came to see us off. I didn't expect such a reaction myself. It made me very embarrassed." She then expressed, "How kind-hearted and loving they are." This sudden and involuntary gesture by dear Mehrangiz had a profound impact.

As time passed under the conditions created in the Islamic Republic, our third child, Mi-Khanum, married Mr. Ardalan Fadaei, the son of Mr. Houshang Fadaei, who were immigrants from Fariman. A few years later, Mitra Khanum, our first daughter, with her family, and Fariba Khanum, our second daughter, with her family, left Iran and settled in Turkey for a while before migrating to the United States.

In 2009, Mitra Khanum managed to obtain residency in the United States for her parents, and to achieve this, the two of us traveled to Ankara for an in-person interview at the U.S. Embassy. After the interview and acceptance on the first visit, we returned to Iran, until a month later when we had to go back to Ankara to collect our green card from the U.S. Embassy and go to America.

The value of Iranian currency was still strong. By spending six million tomans, we purchased two tickets from Mashhad to Los Angeles, USA, via Turkish Airlines, and our first trip was very comfortable. In Los Angeles, after visiting insurance and security offices, our initial ten-year residency was issued.

As time passed, our dear granddaughter, Shamis Khanum, received her diploma with excellent grades. However, she was worried about the cost of medical school in the United States, which was about 350 to 400 thousand dollars. Since the properties and assets of Shamis's paternal family in Iran were confiscated or in a state of seizure, no assistance from Iran was conceivable. On the other hand, I myself, as her maternal grandfather, was banned from transactions after the confiscation of the Ahvaz house. But these were not reasons to sit idly by and do nothing.

In Canada, Mr. Dariush Mahmoudi, the brother of the martyr Mr. Majid Houshang Mahmoudi, who were immigrants in Aden and with whom we spent some time in Lahij, lived. I called Mr. Mahmoudi and after inquiring about his family, I learned that dear Ramin, his son, who was the same age as Mitra and Fariba, was working in Florida, USA. I obtained his phone number from Mr. Dariush Mahmoudi. When I called dear Ramin, he expressed such joy and amazement that I was astonished. The love of the children of Arabian Peninsula immigrants is so deep, sincere, and genuine that dear Ramin's gesture is a cluster from the harvest. Dear Ramin, upon hearing my voice, asked, "From which state are you calling?" I said, "From the state of California, city of Los Angeles." He said, "Tomorrow at ten in the morning, I will be waiting for you and dear Mehrangiz with Mitra and the rest at such-and-such restaurant," and he hung up the phone. He did not give me the opportunity to invite him to Mitra's house. After the phone call ended, I realized that out of sheer happiness that a meeting would take place after many years, he wanted to host us at the restaurant. The next morning, we arrived at the designated restaurant with the entire family of Mitra and dear Mehrangiz.

Dear Ramin had arrived at the restaurant before us. Our meeting was truly remarkable, especially since our questions for Ramin were endless. Finally, we asked him, "Have you married?" He said, "I married my cousin, and my wife is a doctor and works in the U.S. Navy and is very satisfied with her job." We inquired about the cost of university. He said, "Since my cousin came here from Iran without any capital, after extensive research, we discovered that the U.S. Navy accepts students in all fields and pays sufficient salaries to students during their studies. After completing four years of college, they work with a suitable salary in the Navy. It only has a small condition that they must commit to serving in the Navy for the duration of their studies. Now, even though my wife's commitment has ended, she continues to work. Dear Ramin's explanations helped us find solutions for dear Shamis. Dear Shamis was able to enroll in the Navy's university without paying any fees and study, and after receiving her specialization in ophthalmology, she was employed by the Navy. Now, as I write these memories, 13 years have passed since that time, and our dear Shamis has become a specialist eye surgeon, a mother of two beautiful children, and a loving wife.

After six months of staying in the United States, we were preparing to return to Iran. The children insisted on us staying and settling permanently, but Mehrangiz and I had decided to return to Iran and, if possible, visit the U.S. every few years. They said if you leave the U.S. and stay in Iran for a long time, returning would be problematic. After extensive research, we realized that U.S. lawmakers had thought of this issue. By visiting the immigration office, filling out a special form, fingerprinting, and paying the related fee, one could stay outside the U.S. for up to two years without any worries and then return with a residence permit, or Green Card. We used this law, and despite the expiration of the first ten-year Green Card and receiving the second ten-year one, we have taken a white passport six times and stayed in Iran for two years or more each time. Interestingly, on each trip to the U.S., we managed to accomplish something unexpected.

A while after Shamis's wedding, we planned a trip to Turkey with Shamis, Chris, Fariba, Mitra, me, and some family members from Iran, which was very enjoyable. Especially since during this trip, Shamis was supposed to inform us of her first pregnancy, and after birth, the child was named Aram. On the next trip to the U.S., we celebrated the wedding of our dear Mona, Fariba's eldest daughter, our second beloved grandchild. Mona married a young man from Argentina who is very warm-hearted. Now, in 2025, they have twin sons.

To make the most of the passports granted by the Islamic Republic, we planned a trip with all the children, some grandchildren, and some family members from Iran to Baku, Azerbaijan. One of the interesting things we saw in Baku was the installation of a statue of Tahirih (Qurrat al-Ayn) in one of Baku's squares.

When receiving a passport, one had to specify their religion on the application form, and we clearly stated our religion. The passport office, after recording the information we provided, stored the exact details of our signed form in the computer, added the applicant's photo, stamped it, and returned the exact form to us. This same paper or form, during one of our trips to the U.S., brought joy and happiness to the friends. We went with Mitra and her mother to a meeting at the Haziratu'l-Quds in Los Angeles. Since Mitra had many friends, we lost her before entering the Haziratu'l-Quds hall. Upon entering the meeting, a lady responsible for checking attendees, who did not know us, asked, 'Where are you from?' We replied, 'From Iran.' She asked, 'Do you have a letter of introduction?' Since the Bahá'í administrative structures in Iran were dissolved during the Islamic Republic, and it was impossible to obtain an official letter, I said we did not have one. But I informed her that we were Mitra Kholousi's parents, whom she knew. However, the lady, who seemed to take her duty very seriously, was hesitant about what to do. I immediately showed the Iranian police paper related to the passport application, which explicitly stated our religion as Bahá'í and was adorned with the passport office's stamp. This caused laughter and joy among the gathering, and Mitra arrived as well.

On the next trip to the U.S., we attended the wedding of dear Sara, Fariba's second daughter, in San Diego. The groom, Mr. Navid Ardakani, was originally from Yazd and had studied and lived in the U.S. Before traveling to the U.S. to attend Sara and Navid's wedding, our third grandchild, Saghieh Fadaei, married Mr. Tawfiq Foroughi, a distinguished young man from Mashhad, and they happily embarked on their married life. Saghieh's younger sister, Setareh Fadaei, went to Portugal to continue her university studies. Both Saghieh and Setareh are the children of (Me and Ardalan Fadaei), with Me being our last child, born in Aden. As I write these memories, Sara is in the U.S., and Saghieh is in Mashhad, each with beautiful, sweet-talking daughters aged one. And at 88 years old, I have 7 grandchildren and 6 great-grandchildren, and my heart beats with hope for the health and success of these dear ones.

There was a delay in writing these materials, and now that I have decided to continue writing again, unexpected problems have arisen. I remember in school, the handwriting teacher gave a sample saying, 'Do what you can while you can, before you can do nothing.' Now, due to the insistence of the children, I have decided to continue writing memories, but it is observed that due to old age, firstly, memory has lost its efficiency, and secondly, with the pain that extends from the neck to the right shoulder, the fingers of the right hand do not cooperate sufficiently to hold the pen and write. But what can be done? The children say to continue, and I hope to complete this important task with Mitra's cooperation during the trip to Turkey.

In Mashhad, it was customary for friends to visit the families of martyrs or those who had ascended to God on the first day of Nowruz. The first year of martyrdom was for the martyr Majid, Mr. Azizollah Golshani. Mehrangiz and I went to pay our respects at the home of dear Mr. Golshani, where we met with a group of loyal friends who were there with the same intention. Mr. Golshani's daughters and sons-in-law, who had come from Tehran, were also present. After some conversation, I asked Mrs. Khadijeh, Mr. Golshani's wife, 'Do you have any notes from Mr. Golshani regarding the early history of the Bahá'í Faith in Bashruyeh?' To clarify, Mr. Dr. Firooz Baraghi, the grandson of Mr. Mirza Habibollah Baraghi, one of the early Bahá'ís of Bashruyeh, who was a professor at Jundi Shapur University in Ahvaz and had moved to Canada after the Islamic Revolution, had entrusted his residential property to me through a power of attorney. Unfortunately, the Islamic Republic did not pay his pension, and they also confiscated his house and ours.
